subject: Re: Questions on Final Project Part 2
content: I had triggers that were running while i did my publish From: Koushik Kumar Varma Nallaparaju <knallap@g.clemson.edu> Sent: Friday, April 4, 2025 8:09 PM To: Marc Leavitt <leavitt@clemson.edu> Cc: Connie Taylor <connie2@clemson.edu>; Gary Matthew Webb <gmwebb@clemson.edu> Subject: Re: Questions on Final Project Part 2 Even I am not sure, which one is running first! On Fri, Apr 4, 2025 at 20:03 Marc Leavitt <leavitt@clemson.edu> wrote: I can confirm that enabling the triggers before running PopulateData.sql logically corrupts the data From: Marc Leavitt <leavitt@clemson.edu> Sent: Friday, April 4, 2025 4:53 PM To: Koushik Kumar Varma Nallaparaju <knallap@g.clemson.edu> Cc: Connie Taylor <connie2@clemson.edu>; Gary Matthew Webb <gmwebb@clemson.edu> Subject: Re: Questions on Final Project Part 2 Sorry Koushik, but I'm still confused on the triggers. If they are enabled, so let me lay this out carefully. I have triggers on insert and update of pizza_topping, pizza_discount, and order_discount (and yes, the triggers use stored functions) that update pizza and order prices+costs (incl discounts) If the triggers are enabled while the autograder is populating any of those 3 tables (), there's a pretty good chance that the price and cost of the pizza and/or order is going to be set wrong In the autograder environment, I don't have control over when the triggers are enabled In my local environment, I address this by not enabling the triggers (and functions and SPs) until after the non-transactional tables (customer, discount, baseprice, topping) are populated. Then I run a local script (not submitted to not confuse the autograder) that use the stored automation and triggers to populate ordertable, order_discount, pizza, pizza_discount, and pizza_topping. This works great in my local environment I thought this was in-line with our previous email, but we're concerned that the triggers get executed at the wrong time and cause the grader to fail tests Questions: Have I made the concern clear? Is it okay to have triggers changing order and pizza price & cost? IMPORTANT: My partner (Gary) is super-jammed tonight, but he has been handling the submissions for our team. Can I take over doing submissions for our team tonight? Thanks & sorry, I thought this was in-the-can several hours ago. From: Koushik Kumar Varma Nallaparaju <knallap@g.clemson.edu> Sent: Thursday, April 3, 2025 9:22 AM To: Marc Leavitt <leavitt@clemson.edu> Cc: Connie Taylor <connie2@clemson.edu>; Gary Matthew Webb <gmwebb@clemson.edu> Subject: Re: Questions on Final Project Part 2 Hi Marc, 1. For now, yes. They shouldn’t need to modify the topping inventory. They are already deducted and given to you. You need to apply order discounts. Pizza discount is applied and given to you! 2. They will be executed and manually verified as well! 3. You can use them! Best, Koushik. On Wed, Apr 2, 2025 at 23:50 Marc Leavitt <leavitt@clemson.edu> wrote: A short list this time: Does "You do not need to deduct from the inventory for these orders (it has already been taken into account)" effectively mean that our SPs and functions should not modify topping inventory? More generally, will the autograder execute our triggers, SPs, and functions? Or is that more of a manual grading step? Just trying to think about autograder compliations… Should we be implementing CASCADEs on e.g., deletion of a pizza or an order? Or is this a bad idea? Thanks, Marc

subject: Important Upcoming Dates
content: Hi all, I am emailing to remind you of some important upcoming dates. First, the last day to withdraw from classes without a final grade is Monday, Oct 28th. This window ends at 11:59pm ET, so if you feel you may need to withdraw from a class, you need to do so before that date/time in order to not receive a final grade. The course will still appear on your transcript; however, your grade would show a “W” and does not impact your GPA. After this date/time, you will receive a final grade for the course. Second, registration for the Spring 2025 semester begins on Wednesday, November 6th at 8am ET. We will be offering both of the PBA courses (CPSC 8400 and 8740) in the Spring, and we will also be adding CPSC 6300, CPSC 6620, and HCC 6600 to the courses available through Coursera. If you have any questions about withdrawing or registration, please let me know by sending an email to mscscoursera@clemson.edu. Kind regards, Becca Spilka Graduate Services Coordinator School of Computing College of Engineering, Computing, and Applied Sciences

subject: Start Your Spring Semester with Our Popular GIS Workshops!
content: Dear Marc, I hope you had a fantastic winter break! As you plan your spring semester, we’re excited to announce the return of our highly popular GIS Fundamentals Workshop Series. These workshops provide a unique opportunity to gain hands-on experience with GIS concepts, software, and techniques. Designed for all skill levels, they help you acquire valuable GIS skills that are highly sought after in both research and the job market. No prior experience is needed—our workshops start with the basics. Plus, they’re free and open to all Clemson students, faculty, and staff. Last year, over 4,400 participants registered for our workshops! What’s New This Spring? This semester, we’re rolling out an updated curriculum for our GIS Fundamentals Workshop Series, tailored to empower attendees with expertise in the world’s leading desktop GIS application, ArcGIS Pro. We’ve streamlined our offerings into six essential topics that cover all the GIS fundamentals: 1. Introduction to GIS with ArcGIS Pro*Friday, January 17 2. GIS Data Creation and Management*Friday, January 31 3. Working with Tabular Data in GISFriday, February 14 4. Basic Spatial AnalysisFriday, February 28 5. Intermediate Spatial AnalysisFriday, March 14 6. Introduction to Spatial StatisticsFriday, March 28 How to Participate Format: Hybrid (online or in-person) In-Person: Cooper Library, Rooms 406A and 412 (limited to 32 seats). Our staff will be available to assist during the sessions, which will also be live-streamed on large screens. Online: A session link will be provided after registration. Time: Every other Friday, from 1:30 p.m. to 4:30 p.m. Registration: Pre-registration is required for each workshop at bit.ly/ccgtworkshops. * Please note that attendance at the first two workshops is mandatory to participate in the remaining sessions. Earn a Certificate Participants who attend all six workshops and complete assignments on time will receive a CCGT Certificate of Attendance. Please feel free to forward this message to anyone who may be interested. Wishing you a great start to your semester! Clemson Center for Geospatial Technologies

subject: What's Happening in the Gantt Center?
content: Hello, students! Please see the information below about our upcoming events. We hope to see you soon! 1. International Festival – Vendor Sign Up 2. Gantt Stole 3. Paid Mentorship Opportunity 4. Now Hiring: UPIC Intern 1. International Festival Call for Vendors Interested Vendors sign up by Tuesday, April 1st at 11:59 PM at this link Save the date for the 2025 International Festival on Tuesday, April 15th! This annual event brings people together to enjoy food and traditions from around the world. A favorite among students and community members alike, the festival features food, performances, and activities for all ages. We are inviting international and cultural student organizations to showcase unique aspects of their heritage through dance, music, food, artifacts, and demonstrations. Join us in making this a memorable experience for the Clemson community! If your organization is interested in participating in this year’s festival as a vendor or performer, follow the link to sign up. Visit https://bit.ly/cuinternationalfestival or contact Rebecca Harkless at rharkle@clemson.edu for more information or questions. 2. Gantt Stole Registration Registration deadline Tuesday, April 1st at 11:59 PM at this link We are excited to offer all 2025 graduates the opportunity to get a Gantt graduation stole. The stole is a symbol of prestige and an official rite of passage. The Kente cloth was developed in the 17th century by the Ashanti people of Ghana as a form of royal regalia considered to be a symbol of accomplishment and prestige. The Kente is often reserved for special occasions and the colors and markings signify special meanings. The Gantt stoles are black, denoting a rite of passage, with purple and orange stripes that represent Clemson University. The Siamese Crocodile is a symbol of democracy and unity. The Gantt name embroidered on the stole carries a two-fold meaning: first, to honor the legacy of Harvey and Lucinda Gantt, and second, to express the Gantt Center’s gratitude for the graduates’ contributions to the Clemson community during their time as students, and now as alumni. To receive the Gantt Stole, students must be a May, August, or December graduate and are REQUIRED to register. Stoles are very limited and will be reserved on a first-come, first-served basis. Registration does NOT guarantee a stole. You will be notified on Thursday, April 3rd, of the status of your registration. If you would like to request a stole, please REGISTER HERE. 3. Join The 1963 Academy as a Mentor Application Deadline Extended - Monday, April 7th at 11:59 PM at this link Founded on the legacy of Harvey and Lucinda Gantt, The 1963 Academy fosters a community of motivated scholars through mentorship, guidance, and support. Our mentors play a pivotal role in helping students succeed academically, personally, and professionally—all within a supportive environment that empowers them to reach their full potential. Visit bit.ly/1963MentorApp25 for more information and to apply. Requirements: • Minimum 3.0 GPA • All majors welcome • Rising Junior or Senior status (Graduating Spring 2026 or later) • Must submit a resume • Provide one reference (faculty, advisor, or staff) able to offer a strong recommendation • Attend required mentor training and professional development workshops Desired Qualities: • Demonstrated leadership and ability to motivate others • Strong communication and rapport-building skills • Reliability, accountability, and effective time management • Willingness to listen, guide, and support mentees in a non-judgmental manner If you have any questions, please reach out to Iman Johnson at imanj@clemson.edu. 4. Gantt is Hiring: Apply to be our UPIC Graphic Design Intern Find the listing by searching “Gantt” on ClemsonJobLink to apply The Harvey and Lucinda Gantt Multicultural Center is seeking a graphic design intern with social media management skills for the 2025-2026 academic year to assist in creating content for both on- and off-campus use. The desired skills for this position are as follows: · Experience with graphic design. · Proficiency in Adobe InDesign, Illustrator and Photoshop. · The ability to conduct operations analysis and design to meet marketing needs adequately. · Creativity and originality in design. · Problem-solving skills. · Skills in social media management preferred. · 3.0+ GPA Preferred majors: Graphic Communications; Marketing with Graphic Comm minor. Please reach out to Iman Johnson at imanj@clemson.edu if you have any questions. Email: CUGantt@clemson.edu Phone: 864-656-7625 Facebook: facebook.com/CUGantt Instagram: instagram.com/CUGantt

I.e., it should clearly populate the non-transactional tables (baseprice, customer, topping, discount), but should it also populate the transactional tables (ordertable, pickup, delivery, dinein, order_discount, pizza, pizza_discount, and pizza_topping)? I'm asking because, at this point, our automation + a 'add all the orders' script generates a complete post order entry database & I can just use `mysqldump --no-create-info --skip-triggers --skip-routines` to get a script that will regenerate that complete database. I just don't want to submit that if what you really want is to just populate the non-transactional tables. Let me know if that doesn't make sense 😉 Thanks, Marc From: Koushik Kumar Varma Nallaparaju <knallap@g.clemson.edu> Sent: Friday, April 4, 2025 1:36 PM To: Marc Leavitt <leavitt@clemson.edu> Cc: Connie Taylor <connie2@clemson.edu>; Gary Matthew Webb <gmwebb@clemson.edu> Subject: Re: Possible error in Part 2 order #4 info Yes with 9.19 all the values are correct. For you need to have 9.19 for part 2! Best, Koushik. On Fri, Apr 4, 2025 at 16:25 Marc Leavitt <leavitt@clemson.edu> wrote: Thanks Koushik! Can you please verify that all of the autograder expected results have been updated (e.g., obviously ProfitByPizza view is impacted) Thanks again From: Koushik Kumar Varma Nallaparaju <knallap@g.clemson.edu> Sent: Friday, April 4, 2025 12:34 PM To: Marc Leavitt <leavitt@clemson.edu> Subject: Re: Possible error in Part 2 order #4 info Hi Marc, Yes, thanks for bringing that up! it should be 5.59 but it is given as 9.19 by mistake and should use that to pass the autograder for now! Best, Koushik. On Fri, Apr 4, 2025 at 15:15 Marc Leavitt <leavitt@clemson.edu> wrote: Apologies that this is arriving late, this would up being a considerably more code that I (naively) assumed. I think that there may be a problem with the cost of the first pizza in order #4 (highlighted below): #4. On April 20th at 7:11 pm there was a delivery order made by Andrew Wilkes-Krier for 1 xlarge pepperoni and Sausage pizza (Price: $27.94, Cost: $9.19), one xlarge pizza with Ham (extra) and Pineapple (extra) pizza (Price: $31.50, Cost: $6.25), and one xlarge Chicken and Bacon pizza (Price: $26.75, Cost: $5.55). All the pizzas have the Four Cheese Blend on it and are original crust. The order has the “Gameday Special” discount applied to it, and the ham and pineapple pizza has the “Specialty Pizza” discount applied to it. The pizzas were delivered to 115 Party Blvd, Anderson SC 29621. His phone number is the same as before. I have run this calculation manually and via our automation many (so many) times and the answer I keep getting is $5.5875 -> $5.59. As a sanity cross-check, it does not seem reasonable that the first pizza in that order should be quite a bit more expensive than the other two pizzas of the same size (even accounting for the “Specialty Pizza” discount). Don't worry, at this point I'm not waiting on your response 😉 (unless of course I've missed something really dumb here). Just pointing it out.

subject: Re: Questions on Project Part 1: Database Design
content: The instructions say to use crowsfoot ERD and not EERM right? Get Outlook for Android From: Koushik Kumar Varma Nallaparaju <knallap@g.clemson.edu> Sent: Tuesday, March 11, 2025 1:29:30 PM To: Marc Leavitt <leavitt@clemson.edu> Cc: Connie Taylor <connie2@clemson.edu>; Gary Matthew Webb <gmwebb@clemson.edu> Subject: Re: Questions on Project Part 1: Database Design Yes, it should be rendered as shown in lectures! Best regards, Koushik. On Tue, Mar 11, 2025 at 13:27 Marc Leavitt <leavitt@clemson.edu> wrote: One follow-up question: Should the specialization hierarchy be rendered as demonstrated in the textbook and lectures or should it be rendered with adapted Crow's Foot notation? Thank you From: Connie Taylor <connie2@clemson.edu> Sent: Saturday, March 8, 2025 12:52 PM To: Marc Leavitt <leavitt@clemson.edu>; Koushik Kumar Varma Nallaparaju <knallap@g.clemson.edu>; Gary Matthew Webb <gmwebb@clemson.edu> Subject: Re: Questions on Project Part 1: Database Design Please see answers below. Koushik - please correct me or elaborate where needed. CONNIE TAYLOR Associate Director and Professor of Practice School of Computing, Clemson University o 864-656-5878 connie2@clemson.edu From: Marc Leavitt <leavitt@clemson.edu> Date: Friday, March 7, 2025 at 6:23 PM To: Koushik Kumar Varma Nallaparaju <knallap@g.clemson.edu>, Connie Taylor <connie2@clemson.edu>, Gary Matthew Webb <gmwebb@clemson.edu> Subject: Questions on Project Part 1: Database Design Koushik, My project partner (Gary Webb) and I are drafting the ERD and have compiled the following list of questions, in no particular order: Do rooms have a cost? Do schools?Are they required entities? I think the location field covers it. Do we need this?All you need is a class and class cost. Do assistant leaders have a cost? What if they're volunteers? Only the primary leader has the cost. Do sessions have a price? I.e., that non-leading students pay? If so, do assistant leaders have to pay? Not needed Do we need to document cardinality? (vs. connectivity) No, cardinality is not required to be documented, but implied from the ERD relationships. Are we okay expanding the student attributes? I.e., adding basic contact information? Sure. Extra attributes are fine. Do we need to describe levels in addition to naming them? I would describe them. The business rules mention "schools" and "rooms"—are schools important to location? Or should we just have "LOCATION" that has school and room identifiers? You can just specify the location as part of the class information but not needed as a separate entity. Do we need to track student class attendance history? You should have this information included in one of your entities. Do we need to track history of sessions/leaders? You should have this information included in one of your entities. Should we subclass 'LEADER' & use specialization hierarchy? Yes Is the assignment of leaders at a class level or session level? This is a design decision - document what you decide in the rational you are providing. Do we need to use the dependency diagram notations, EERM? The dependency diagram is unnecessary; however, you should think about your ERD and ensure it is in 3NF. Do we connect relationships at an entity or attribute level for the Relationships are always between entities ? Not sure I understand your question. connectors14) What does an A grade look like? What do we need to do to make it happen. ERD that meets the requirements and we can use rationale to validate your decisions. There are different ways to implement this. Do we need to track students' date of joining? Enroll date? Yes Please let us know if any of the questions need to be clarified. Thanks, Marc

subject: Re: Feedback on Q1 of Module 8 Application (Part 1)
content: I am not sure regarding other RDBMSs, but MYSQL and most of the RDBMSs treat the trigger as a statement level trigger. Best wishes, Koushik. On Thu, Mar 20, 2025 at 6:10 PM Marc Leavitt <leavitt@clemson.edu> wrote: While I'm whining, I am also confused by Q10 of the "Module 8 Quiz: Advanced SQL" (see attached). I guess you could argue that this might be true for RDBMSs other than MySQL but, my 2¢, it seems like kind of a syntactic trick question. From: Marc Leavitt <leavitt@clemson.edu> Sent: Thursday, March 20, 2025 2:45 PM To: Koushik Kumar Varma Nallaparaju <knallap@g.clemson.edu> Cc: Connie Taylor <connie2@clemson.edu> Subject: Re: Feedback on Q1 of Module 8 Application (Part 1) Thanks! From: Koushik Kumar Varma Nallaparaju <knallap@g.clemson.edu> Sent: Thursday, March 20, 2025 2:40 PM To: Marc Leavitt <leavitt@clemson.edu> Cc: Connie Taylor <connie2@clemson.edu> Subject: Re: Feedback on Q1 of Module 8 Application (Part 1) Hi Marc, It seems the option you marked was correct as well, Let us look into it and update the option. Best wishes, Koushik. On Thu, Mar 20, 2025 at 5:36 PM Marc Leavitt <leavitt@clemson.edu> wrote: I'm not clear on why my answer is 'Incorrect' (see attached screenshot). I simply went with creating tables without any FKs first, rather than following the 1:M relationships around the ERD, which is a pattern that you have to break when you get to 'Treatment_Apt' anyway. I don't know if it's intentional or not but I'm pretty sure the key designations for 'Treatment_Apt' are incorrect—I think TREATMENT_ID & APPOINTMENT_ID are both attributes of a composite PK and also that they are both independently FKs In Treatment, TREATMENT_ID is both misspelled ('TREAMENT_ID', i.e., missing the second 'T'), and mislabeled as an FK The third answer option is missing a comma between 'Pet' and 'Appointments' Thank you

I'm asking because, at this point, our automation + a 'add all the orders' script generates a complete post order entry database & I can just use `mysqldump --no-create-info --skip-triggers --skip-routines` to get a script that will regenerate that complete database. I just don't want to submit that if what you really want is to just populate the non-transactional tables. Let me know if that doesn't make sense 😉 Thanks, Marc From: Koushik Kumar Varma Nallaparaju <knallap@g.clemson.edu> Sent: Friday, April 4, 2025 1:36 PM To: Marc Leavitt <leavitt@clemson.edu> Cc: Connie Taylor <connie2@clemson.edu>; Gary Matthew Webb <gmwebb@clemson.edu> Subject: Re: Possible error in Part 2 order #4 info Yes with 9.19 all the values are correct. For you need to have 9.19 for part 2! Best, Koushik. On Fri, Apr 4, 2025 at 16:25 Marc Leavitt <leavitt@clemson.edu> wrote: Thanks Koushik! Can you please verify that all of the autograder expected results have been updated (e.g., obviously ProfitByPizza view is impacted) Thanks again From: Koushik Kumar Varma Nallaparaju <knallap@g.clemson.edu> Sent: Friday, April 4, 2025 12:34 PM To: Marc Leavitt <leavitt@clemson.edu> Subject: Re: Possible error in Part 2 order #4 info Hi Marc, Yes, thanks for bringing that up! it should be 5.59 but it is given as 9.19 by mistake and should use that to pass the autograder for now! Best, Koushik. On Fri, Apr 4, 2025 at 15:15 Marc Leavitt <leavitt@clemson.edu> wrote: Apologies that this is arriving late, this would up being a considerably more code that I (naively) assumed. I think that there may be a problem with the cost of the first pizza in order #4 (highlighted below): #4. On April 20th at 7:11 pm there was a delivery order made by Andrew Wilkes-Krier for 1 xlarge pepperoni and Sausage pizza (Price: $27.94, Cost: $9.19), one xlarge pizza with Ham (extra) and Pineapple (extra) pizza (Price: $31.50, Cost: $6.25), and one xlarge Chicken and Bacon pizza (Price: $26.75, Cost: $5.55). All the pizzas have the Four Cheese Blend on it and are original crust. The order has the “Gameday Special” discount applied to it, and the ham and pineapple pizza has the “Specialty Pizza” discount applied to it. The pizzas were delivered to 115 Party Blvd, Anderson SC 29621. His phone number is the same as before. I have run this calculation manually and via our automation many (so many) times and the answer I keep getting is $5.5875 -> $5.59. As a sanity cross-check, it does not seem reasonable that the first pizza in that order should be quite a bit more expensive than the other two pizzas of the same size (even accounting for the “Specialty Pizza” discount). Don't worry, at this point I'm not waiting on your response 😉 (unless of course I've missed something really dumb here). Just pointing it out.

content: We are trying to figure out if we should show the circle with a "d" inside of it style notation or if basic crowsfoot is ok to model the subtype. Best regards, Koushik. Thank you From: Connie Taylor <connie2@clemson.edu> Sent: Saturday, March 8, 2025 12:52 PM To: Marc Leavitt <leavitt@clemson.edu>; Koushik Kumar Varma Nallaparaju <knallap@g.clemson.edu>; Gary Matthew Webb <gmwebb@clemson.edu> Subject: Re: Questions on Project Part 1: Database Design Please see answers below. Koushik - please correct me or elaborate where needed. CONNIE TAYLOR Associate Director and Professor of Practice School of Computing, Clemson University o 864-656-5878 connie2@clemson.edu From: Marc Leavitt <leavitt@clemson.edu> Date: Friday, March 7, 2025 at 6:23 PM To: Koushik Kumar Varma Nallaparaju <knallap@g.clemson.edu>, Connie Taylor <connie2@clemson.edu>, Gary Matthew Webb <gmwebb@clemson.edu> Subject: Questions on Project Part 1: Database Design Koushik, My project partner (Gary Webb) and I are drafting the ERD and have compiled the following list of questions, in no particular order: Do rooms have a cost? Do schools?Are they required entities? I think the location field covers it. Do we need this?All you need is a class and class cost. Do assistant leaders have a cost? What if they're volunteers? Only the primary leader has the cost. Do sessions have a price? I.e., that non-leading students pay? If so, do assistant leaders have to pay? Not needed Do we need to document cardinality? (vs. connectivity) No, cardinality is not required to be documented, but implied from the ERD relationships. Are we okay expanding the student attributes? I.e., adding basic contact information? Sure. Extra attributes are fine. Do we need to describe levels in addition to naming them? I would describe them. The business rules mention "schools" and "rooms"—are schools important to location? Or should we just have "LOCATION" that has school and room identifiers? You can just specify the location as part of the class information but not needed as a separate entity. Do we need to track student class attendance history? You should have this information included in one of your entities. Do we need to track history of sessions/leaders? You should have this information included in one of your entities. Should we subclass 'LEADER' & use specialization hierarchy? Yes Is the assignment of leaders at a class level or session level? This is a design decision - document what you decide in the rational you are providing. Do we need to use the dependency diagram notations, EERM? The dependency diagram is unnecessary; however, you should think about your ERD and ensure it is in 3NF. Do we connect relationships at an entity or attribute level for the Relationships are always between entities ? Not sure I understand your question. connectors14) What does an A grade look like? What do we need to do to make it happen. ERD that meets the requirements and we can use rationale to validate your decisions. There are different ways to implement this. Do we need to track students' date of joining? Enroll date? Yes Please let us know if any of the questions need to be clarified. Thanks, Marc

subject: Re: Questions on Final Project Part 2
content: My recommendation would be to not touch the data values with the triggers On Apr 4, 2025, at 8:50 PM, Marc Leavitt <leavitt@clemson.edu> wrote: Key points: I'm at a lost for how to submit triggers when the autograder's order-of-execution ensures that triggers that update order and/or pizza price & cost logically corrupt the db When I submit with the triggers commented out in CreateSPs.sql, the submission gets 150/150 I don't see a clean way in MySQL to disable and re-enable triggers without depending on extra tables (which I assume will be a problem for the autograder) or session variables which I don't have a lot of faith would work in the autograder environment either. So, I propose that we submit the `CreateSPs.sql` with the triggers commented out, with the understanding that the triggers will be reviewed manually. Make sense? Thanks yet again From: Koushik Kumar Varma Nallaparaju <knallap@g.clemson.edu> Sent: Friday, April 4, 2025 5:10 PM To: Marc Leavitt <leavitt@clemson.edu> Cc: Connie Taylor <connie2@clemson.edu>; Gary Matthew Webb <gmwebb@clemson.edu> Subject: Re: Questions on Final Project Part 2 I am not completely sure, It is ok to change the data pizza price, order price. But they should match the output as expected by autograder On Fri, Apr 4, 2025 at 19:53 Marc Leavitt <leavitt@clemson.edu> wrote: Sorry Koushik, but I'm still confused on the triggers. If they are enabled, so let me lay this out carefully. I have triggers on insert and update of pizza_topping, pizza_discount, and order_discount (and yes, the triggers use stored functions) that update pizza and order prices+costs (incl discounts) If the triggers are enabled while the autograder is populating any of those 3 tables (), there's a pretty good chance that the price and cost of the pizza and/or order is going to be set wrong In the autograder environment, I don't have control over when the triggers are enabled In my local environment, I address this by not enabling the triggers (and functions and SPs) until after the non-transactional tables (customer, discount, baseprice, topping) are populated. Then I run a local script (not submitted to not confuse the autograder) that use the stored automation and triggers to populate ordertable, order_discount, pizza, pizza_discount, and pizza_topping. This works great in my local environment I thought this was in-line with our previous email, but we're concerned that the triggers get executed at the wrong time and cause the grader to fail tests Questions: Have I made the concern clear? Is it okay to have triggers changing order and pizza price & cost? IMPORTANT: My partner (Gary) is super-jammed tonight, but he has been handling the submissions for our team. Can I take over doing submissions for our team tonight? Thanks & sorry, I thought this was in-the-can several hours ago. From: Koushik Kumar Varma Nallaparaju <knallap@g.clemson.edu> Sent: Thursday, April 3, 2025 9:22 AM To: Marc Leavitt <leavitt@clemson.edu> Cc: Connie Taylor <connie2@clemson.edu>; Gary Matthew Webb <gmwebb@clemson.edu> Subject: Re: Questions on Final Project Part 2 Hi Marc, 1. For now, yes. They shouldn’t need to modify the topping inventory. They are already deducted and given to you. You need to apply order discounts. Pizza discount is applied and given to you! 2. They will be executed and manually verified as well! 3. You can use them! Best, Koushik. On Wed, Apr 2, 2025 at 23:50 Marc Leavitt <leavitt@clemson.edu> wrote: A short list this time: Does "You do not need to deduct from the inventory for these orders (it has already been taken into account)" effectively mean that our SPs and functions should not modify topping inventory? More generally, will the autograder execute our triggers, SPs, and functions? Or is that more of a manual grading step? Just trying to think about autograder compliations… Should we be implementing CASCADEs on e.g., deletion of a pizza or an order? Or is this a bad idea? Thanks, Marc

content: Make sure you match the expected output, then it will be fine. Also make sure that you match the case with the DB Load file. Best, Koushik. On Mon, Mar 3, 2025 at 9:37 PM Marc Leavitt <leavitt@clemson.edu> wrote: Koushik, Thanks for the help on Module 07 SQL Lab - PracticeSet01! I now have a question on the Module 7 Lab Problem Sets—I have only worked through ProblemSet01 so far and I used ROUND() in several of the solutions to match the format of the expected result. E.g., For Problem 6, the expected result is as follows: … -- The results of running that query are shown below: -- -- +---------+------------+-------------------+--------------------+ -- | EMP_NUM | EMP_LNAME | SumOfASSIGN_HOURS | SumOfASSIGN_CHARGE | -- +---------+------------+-------------------+--------------------+ -- | 101 | News | 3.1 | 387.50 | -- | 103 | Arbough | 19.7 | 1664.65 | -- | 104 | Ramoras | 11.9 | 1218.70 | -- | 105 | Johnson | 12.5 | 1382.50 | -- | 108 | Washington | 8.3 | 840.15 | -- | 113 | Joenbrood | 3.8 | 192.85 | -- | 115 | Bawangi | 12.5 | 1276.75 | -- | 117 | Williamson | 18.8 | 649.54 | -- +---------+------------+-------------------+--------------------+ The key point being that the results in the 'SumOfASSIGN_CHARGE' column have 2 digits to the right of the decimal. So, my solution was to use ROUND() as follows: /* YOUR SOLUTION HERE */ SELECT ASSIGNMENT.EMP_NUM, EMP_LNAME, ROUND(SUM(ASSIGN_HOURS), 1) AS 'SumOfASSIGN_HOURS', ROUND(SUM(ASSIGN_CHARGE), 2) AS 'SumOfASSIGN_CHARGE' FROM ASSIGNMENT JOIN EMPLOYEE ON ASSIGNMENT.EMP_NUM = EMPLOYEE.EMP_NUM GROUP BY EMPLOYEE.EMP_NUM ORDER BY EMP_NUM; And I wanted to make sure this wasn't going to confuse the autograder before I submit it. subject: Re: Final Official Transcripts + Registration Update
content: Hi Marc, Thanks for letting us know! The hold for transcripts should be removed from your account. I was notified by Grad Admissions that for students who are completing both PBAs this semester, you will receive a different hold that is waiting for your final grades to publish. Grad Admissions should be sending a notice out, but the reason for this is because if you register now, your courses will get dropped if you pass the PBA courses and receive full admission to the MS. This is unfortunately just a function of our system, but the good news is that you are one step closer to full admission! If you have any follow up questions about this, don't hesitate to reach out! Kind regards, Becca Spilka --------------- Original Message --------------- From: Marc Leavitt [leavitt@clemson.edu] Sent: 11/7/2024, 8:49 AM To: mscscoursera@clemson.edu Subject: Re: Final Official Transcripts + Registration Update Hi! Marc Leavitt (Student ID: C18197647) here. Thanks for the reminder! FYI - I have just received confirmation from Parchment that my transcript "was successfully received by Clemson University - Graduate Programs on 11/06/2024" Thank you, Marc ________________________________ From: MSCS Coursera <mscscoursera@clemson.edu> Sent: Friday, November 1, 2024 6:59 AM Subject: Final Official Transcripts + Registration Update Hi all, I have an update regarding the submission of Final Official Transcripts that may impact your registration next week. For Final Official Transcripts, you must submit these to Clemson’s Graduate School within your first semester of enrollment. If you do not, then there is a hold placed on your account that will prevent you from registering. You can check your account for this transcript hold (as well as other holds) by logging into iRoar > Student Self-Service > under Student Records header > Advising Student Profile. From here, you will see a notification for holds in the top, right corner. Any holds that will prevent registration should provide specific instructions on how to remove the hold, but if you have any questions or concerns about the holds, please let me know! If your undergraduate university is in the US and offers virtual transcripts, then it should only take a few days to receive the transcript and update your profile. However, if you must mail in your transcript, then this process may take a bit longer. The very good news is that there is no cap on our Coursera classes, so you are still guaranteed a seat, as long as we receive your transcript before the last day to add a class! If you haven’t already, I would recommend that you submit your transcript as soon as possible to avoid any delays. I do want to apologize as normally notifications go out to students throughout the semester with reminders about their final transcripts, but unfortunately, due to a technical error, these notifications were not going out. Additionally, I believe some of the language in the orientation module may have been misleading, and we are having that updated! Again, I sincerely apologize for any confusion or inconvenience. However, we can hopefully get everyone sorted before the start of the Spring semester! I’ve attached our Final Official Transcript procedures for your reference. Thank you all so much for your patience! With this being a new program, we might run into a few technical issues along the way, but we are so excited to have you all on board! We hope that you are enjoying the curriculum and are excited to continue in the program! Kind regards, Becca Spilka Graduate Services Coordinator School of Computing College of Engineering, Computing, and Applied Sciences [signature_1757566267]<https://www.clemson.edu/> thread::vSsQtbPPFLC9Po3yclq8Yh8::

subject: Know Before You Go: 2025 Spring Game
content: This Message Is From An External Sender: Use caution when opening links or attachments if you do not recognize the sender. We can't wait to CU in Death Valley! Spring Game Saturday, April 5th! We hope to see you in Death Valley tomorrow, Saturday, April 5th, for the Clemson Football Spring Game, kicking off at 1:00 p.m. Admission is FREE, and gates will open at 11:30 a.m. The only way to watch the 2025 Spring Game is live and in person! Fans can also listen in via the Clemson Athletic Network and ClemsonTigers App. Gameday Events 8:00 a.m.: Parking lots open & Surplus Sale (Littlejohn Coliseum) 9:00 a.m.: Be a T.I.G.E.R. Field Day presented by BASF of Seneca (Littlejohn Coliseum East Lawn) 11:30 a.m.: Tiger Walk, 2024 captains ceremony, and gate open 12:00 p.m.: Warm-ups & drills 1:00 p.m.: Orange & White Game Kickoff For all things Spring Game click on the button below! We can't wait to CU there! Spring Game Guide Be A T.I.G.E.R. Field DayClemson Student-Athlete Development and Clemson student-athletes are set to host the Be A T.I.G.E.R. Field Day presented by BASF in Seneca, a free youth clinic from 9 a.m. – 12 p.m. prior to the Spring Game. The event will take place on the Littlejohn Lawn closest to Memorial Stadium. The event is free and open to children grades Kindergarten through sixth grade. More Info Surplus SaleClemson will hold an equipment Surplus Sale from 8 a.m. – 1 p.m. in Burton Gallery of Littlejohn Coliseum for the first time in several years. Fans can shop for exclusive gear, including jerseys, shoes, polos, jackets, shorts, pants, bags, and more.Surplus Sale Note: Surplus Sale transactions are cashless – no checks or cash will be taken. All fans will enter through the West Entrance of Burton Gallery. More Info Clemson Athletics Alcohol Safety PoliciesIdentification: A valid ID is required for each transaction. Clemson staff and vendors may not serve beer, wine or liquor to anyone under the age of 21. No vertical IDs will be accepted at sales locations regardless of the individual’s age. Students will not be permitted to use Tiger One Cards to purchase alcohol. Service: No service will be permitted to anyone who is visibly intoxicated. No more than two alcoholic beverages may be sold or served per transaction. Sales will begin when the venue doors open. subject: Colloquium Notice - CS Thesis Defense - Bulut Gozubuyuk
content: Colloquium Notice Bulut Gözübüyük MS Candidate, Computer Science Thesis Defense Presentation Wednesday, April 2, 2025 at 2:00PM Remote connection via https://clemson.zoom.us/j/98582419404?pwd=rKb8SfvVY56NpKupzB1Hupb8nMxYBS.1 Title Privacy Implications of Data Collection in Android Automotive OS Abstract Modern vehicles have become sophisticated computational and sensor systems, as evidenced by advanced driver assistance systems (ADAS), in-car infotainment, and autonomous driving capabilities. They collect and process vast amounts of data through various onboard subsystems. One significant player in this landscape is Android Automotive OS (AAOS), which has been integrated into over 100 million vehicles and has become a dominant force in the in-vehicle infotainment (IVI) market. With this extensive data collection, privacy concerns have become increasingly crucial. The volume of data gathered by these systems raises questions about how this information is stored, used, and protected, making privacy a critical issue for manufacturers and consumers. However, very little has been done on vehicle data privacy. This paper focuses on the privacy implications of AAOS by examining the exact nature and scope of its data collection. It also presents a novel automotive privacy analysis tool called PriDrive, which employs three methodological approaches: network traffic inspection, and both static and dynamic analyses of Android images using rooted emulators from various OEMs. Finally, the evaluation on three different OEM platforms reveals that some OEMs collect much more data than others. OEM A collects vehicle speed at a sampling rate of roughly 25 Hz. Meanwhile, other properties such as model info, climate and AC, seat data, and others are collected in a batch 30 seconds into vehicle startup.. Committee Members: Dr. Mert Pese, School of Computing (committee chair); Dr. Long Cheng, School of Computing; Dr. Lu Yu, Electrical and Computer Engineering.

subject: Re: Questions on Project Part 1: Database Design
content: Hi professor, The answers look good to me Best, Koushik. On Sat, Mar 8, 2025 at 15:53 Connie Taylor <connie2@clemson.edu> wrote: Please see answers below. Koushik - please correct me or elaborate where needed. CONNIE TAYLOR Associate Director and Professor of Practice School of Computing, Clemson University o 864-656-5878 connie2@clemson.edu From: Marc Leavitt <leavitt@clemson.edu> Date: Friday, March 7, 2025 at 6:23 PM To: Koushik Kumar Varma Nallaparaju <knallap@g.clemson.edu>, Connie Taylor <connie2@clemson.edu>, Gary Matthew Webb <gmwebb@clemson.edu> Subject: Questions on Project Part 1: Database Design Koushik, My project partner (Gary Webb) and I are drafting the ERD and have compiled the following list of questions, in no particular order: Do rooms have a cost? Do schools?Are they required entities? I think the location field covers it. Do we need this?All you need is a class and class cost. Do assistant leaders have a cost? What if they're volunteers? Only the primary leader has the cost. Do sessions have a price? I.e., that non-leading students pay? If so, do assistant leaders have to pay? Not needed Do we need to document cardinality? (vs. connectivity) No, cardinality is not required to be documented, but implied from the ERD relationships. Are we okay expanding the student attributes? I.e., adding basic contact information? Sure. Extra attributes are fine. Do we need to describe levels in addition to naming them? I would describe them. The business rules mention "schools" and "rooms"—are schools important to location? Or should we just have "LOCATION" that has school and room identifiers? You can just specify the location as part of the class information but not needed as a separate entity. Do we need to track student class attendance history? You should have this information included in one of your entities. Do we need to track history of sessions/leaders? You should have this information included in one of your entities. Should we subclass 'LEADER' & use specialization hierarchy? Yes Is the assignment of leaders at a class level or session level? This is a design decision - document what you decide in the rational you are providing. Do we need to use the dependency diagram notations, EERM? The dependency diagram is unnecessary; however, you should think about your ERD and ensure it is in 3NF. Do we connect relationships at an entity or attribute level for the Relationships are always between entities ? Not sure I understand your question. connectors14) What does an A grade look like? What do we need to do to make it happen. ERD that meets the requirements and we can use rationale to validate your decisions. There are different ways to implement this. Do we need to track students' date of joining? Enroll date? Yes Please let us know if any of the questions need to be clarified. Thanks, Marc

subject: Re: Questions on the Design Rationale requirement for Project Part 1 submission
content: I agree with Koushik’s response. thanks CONNIE TAYLOR Associate Director and Professor of Practice School of Computing, Clemson University o 864-656-5878 connie2@clemson.edu From: Koushik Kumar Varma Nallaparaju <knallap@g.clemson.edu> Date: Friday, March 14, 2025 at 8:00 AM To: Gary Matthew Webb <gmwebb@clemson.edu> Cc: Marc Leavitt <leavitt@clemson.edu>, Connie Taylor <connie2@clemson.edu> Subject: Re: Questions on the Design Rationale requirement for Project Part 1 submission Hi Gary, I feel you should have the discriminator field, because it is the field that is distinguishing between the student and leader. Professor Taylor, correct me if I am wrong, I don't see any 3NF violation because. as the field is not having any transitive dependency with any other attribute in the table. Regarding expanding the hierarchy, If you want to you can increase it. But that is not mandatory to do so. From the image, make sure you use the correct distinguisher(disjoint/overlapping). Best, Koushik On Thu, Mar 13, 2025 at 7:30 PM Gary Matthew Webb <gmwebb@clemson.edu> wrote: Here is a drawing - the supertype discriminator field is in the orange box. From: Gary Matthew Webb <gmwebb@clemson.edu> Sent: Thursday, March 13, 2025 7:13 PM To: Marc Leavitt <leavitt@clemson.edu>; Koushik Kumar Varma Nallaparaju <knallap@g.clemson.edu> Cc: Connie Taylor <connie2@clemson.edu> Subject: Re: Questions on the Design Rationale requirement for Project Part 1 submission Hi team, We have another question regarding our subtype specialization hierarchy notation in the ERD. The guideline suggests we include a discriminator in the supertype, but we currently have a partial disjoint subtype (0..1) with supertype Student and subtype Leader. Adding a discriminator field "is_a_leader" to Student would break 3NF because that field would depend on the existence of a related record in the Leader table rather than solely on the student_id. In our design, if we want to designate a student as a leader, we insert a record into the Leader table and rely on the existence of that record (via the shared PK, FK). This avoids an extra CRUD operation and redundant data. If a student becomes a leader, I would have to do 2 operations: an update to Student.student_is_a_leader and an insert to the Leaders table. So, I have a few questions: Do you want us to add the discriminator field in the supertype anyway? Should we expand our subtype hierarchy by adding additional subtypes (e.g., volunteer, paid, and/or non-leader) and decide whether it should be partial or complete disjoint? Should we simply document this decision in the design rationale and not include a discriminator field in the Student table? Frankly, the 0..1 subtype setup makes my skin crawl because a subtype discriminator in the supertype it would force us into a 3NF violation—something I wouldn’t allow in a production environment. I'm leaning toward not adding the discriminator field and just explaining our rationale in the design documentation. What do you think? Thank you Gary Webb From: Marc Leavitt <leavitt@clemson.edu> Sent: Wednesday, March 12, 2025 2:07 PM To: Koushik Kumar Varma Nallaparaju <knallap@g.clemson.edu> Cc: Connie Taylor <connie2@clemson.edu>; Gary Matthew Webb <gmwebb@clemson.edu> Subject: Re: Questions on the Design Rationale requirement for Project Part 1 submission Perfect. Thanks! From: Koushik Kumar Varma Nallaparaju <knallap@g.clemson.edu> Sent: Wednesday, March 12, 2025 11:05 AM To: Marc Leavitt <leavitt@clemson.edu> Cc: Connie Taylor <connie2@clemson.edu>; Gary Matthew Webb <gmwebb@clemson.edu> Subject: Re: Questions on the Design Rationale requirement for Project Part 1 submission Hi Marc, Yes, the design rationale is due with the ERD. You need to submit a single merged PDF of both ERD and design rationale. (see additional doc for details) It is a reference to the paragraph at the end of the assignment document. Best, Koushik. On Wed, Mar 12, 2025 at 1:58 PM Marc Leavitt <leavitt@clemson.edu> wrote: Just to make sure we're not missing anything: I believe that the design rationale is due with the ERD on 3/16 (zipped PDFs, etc). Please confirm or deny. At the end of the 10th item in the requirements section (the one that first mentions the design rationale document), it says "(see additional doc for details)"—are there additional documents or is this just a reference to the paragraph at the end of the assignment document (pasted below for reference)? ---------------- Design Rationale: This rationale is a brief description (1-2 pages max) of your reasoning in the design process. You should discuss the entities you created and their relationships, citing specific business rules (they are numbered to may this easy). This information is particularly useful for the bridge entities you create and any historical data tables. Pay particular attention to any discriminators that you include in your design. ---------------- Thanks, Marc

content: Hi Marc, I guess you downloaded the previous version of the zip file. We have updated the .zip file (just for problem 13). So you can take a look into it, the expected output will be 112.48. The difference is because of using JOIN / WHERE. When you are joining the entities the count of the users is coming as 8 (because they made 8 purchases). But when you are using where you will be getting 5. That is why there is a difference between both the outputs. I hope this helps. If you have any other questions please let me know. Best, Koushik. On Mon, Mar 10, 2025 at 2:58 PM Marc Leavitt <leavitt@clemson.edu> wrote: Koushik, I was working my way through Problem Set #2 and (maybe) encountered a "situation" on problem 13: I developed a solution that generated output that matches the expected output The I noticed that there was an "extra file" that came in the problem set zip file, "ProblemSet02-Solution13sql", so I took a look and then executed the SQL It turned out that the output from "ProblemSet02-Solution13sql" matched the expected output, except for the averaged column It wasn't immediately clear to me why that solution should be "wrong," so I started playing with it (good learning experience 😉) and realized that, although the output of "ProblemSet02-Solution13.sql" didn't match the expected output, it was probably a better fit for the text of the problem description because I think my solution is going to overcount customers. But, again, it generates output that matches the expected output… It's entirely possible that I'm missing something obvious here, but I wanted to run this by you JIC. My solution: SELECT ROUND(MIN(CUS_BALANCE), 2) AS "Minimum Balance", ROUND(MAX(CUS_BALANCE), 2) AS "Maximum Balance", ROUND(AVG(CUS_BALANCE), 2) AS "Average Balance" FROM CUSTOMER JOIN INVOICE ON CUSTOMER.CUS_CODE = INVOICE.CUS_CODE; "ProblemSet02-Solution13sql" (reformatted): SELECT MIN(CUS_BALANCE) AS 'Minimum Balance', MAX(CUS_BALANCE) AS 'Maximum Balance', ROUND(AVG(CUS_BALANCE), 2) AS 'Average Balance' FROM CUSTOMER WHERE CUS_CODE IN (SELECT DISTINCT CUS_CODE FROM INVOICE); The difference in outputs: My solution/documented expected: "Average Balance" = 70.30 "ProblemSet02-Solution13sql": "Average Balance" = 112.48 I also tried a different variant that generated the same output as "ProblemSet02-Solution13.sql": SELECT ROUND(MIN(CUS_BALANCE), 2) AS "Minimum Balance", ROUND(MAX(CUS_BALANCE), 2) AS "Maximum Balance", ROUND(AVG(CUS_BALANCE), 2) AS "Average Balance" FROM CUSTOMER JOIN (SELECT DISTINCT INVOICE.CUS_CODE FROM INVOICE) CUS_INV ON CUSTOMER.CUS_CODE = CUS_INV.CUS_CODE; Thoughts? Thanks (as always)!

content: Make new friends and level-up your skills. &nb sp; Learn from the community One of the best ways to learn Figma and level-up your skills is by getting involved in the community. Here are a few ways you can get started: Prepare for a career in Design: Catch up on the Figma for Education early career livestream series, including a high-level overview of the design hiring process (how design teams are structured, how to create a strong portfolio, and more) with the Figma Product Design team. Sign up for a Figma event: Register for upcoming live Figma events, including free monthly education workshops for students. Explore the Figma Community: Browse thousands of templates published by professional designers. That's all for now. We're here if you get stuck or have questions. :) Figma is a design platform for teams who build products together. Born on the Web, Figma helps the entire product team create, test, and ship better designs, faster. 760 Market Street, Floor 10 San Francisco, CA, 94102 Unsubscribe from Figma marketing emails.

subject: Colloquium Notice - CS PhD Dissertation Defense - Thomas Randall
content: Colloquium Notice Thomas Randall PhD Candidate, Computer Science Dissertation Defense Presentation Friday, April 11, 2025 at 12:30PM McAdams 106 Remote connection via https://clemson.zoom.us/j/99163737541 Title A Systemic Approach to Maximize Heterogeneous System Performance Abstract Continuous increases in high performance computing (HPC) throughput have served as catalysts for industry and scientific advancement in countless manners that have fundamentally shaped our modern world. Our demands on compute resources continue to scale, but the limitations of Ahmdal's law and Dennard scaling have proven increasingly difficult to overcome when approached solely through hardware or software design. Furthermore, even on the most advanced supercomputers, many HPC applications fail to utilize the collective system's performance. However, the resurgence of AI in industry has promoted an explosion of hardware and software codesign that have fueled massive improvements in GPU design and novel ASICs. These performance improvements are maximized on a broad variety of heterogeneous systems by specially tuning applications. Mimicking these developments across the whole of computing will require similarly holistic approaches combining specialty hardware, software that caters its design to the greatest strength of hardware, and fine-tuning on individual systems to truly maximize performance. In this work, we use three distinct perspectives to holistically address scalable system performance. We analyze the impacts of liquid immersion cooling technologies on sustained application performance and energy efficiency. Next, we present a case study where intentional algorithmic redesign for GPU acceleration permits robust performance improvements that endure through multiple generations of hardware. We find that memory latency forms a primary bottleneck for GPU-accelerated performance and demonstrate how algorithm-specific optimizations can greatly improve performance over multiple architecture generations. Finally, we tie these concepts together in the form of performance optimization techniques that respect both software- and hardware-based performance constraints. We improve the re-usability of performance insights with novel transfer learning techniques that make the cost of performance optimization more predictable and more successful in the short-term. Our insights demonstrate the necessity of systemic approaches for performance tuning in HPC. Committee Members: Dr. Rong Ge, School of Computing (committee chair); Dr. Kai Liu, School of Computing; Dr. Feng Luo, School of Computing; Dr. Xingfu Wu, Argonne National Laboratory

subject: Re: Grading on PracticeSet02-Problem04.sql (0/5)
content: Hi Marc - The autograder is doing a diff, without any fuzzy logic, so it must be an exact match. I agree that your query is correct, but the grader is just not sophisticated enough to deal with those types of nuances. Thanks CONNIE TAYLOR Associate Director and Professor of Practice School of Computing, Clemson University o 864-656-5878 connie2@clemson.edu From: Koushik Kumar Varma Nallaparaju <knallap@g.clemson.edu> Date: Tuesday, March 4, 2025 at 7:07 PM To: Marc Leavitt <leavitt@clemson.edu> Cc: Connie Taylor <connie2@clemson.edu> Subject: Re: Grading on PracticeSet02-Problem04.sql (0/5) Yes Marc, That’s the expected result . That’s the way the autograder is working. Best, Koushik. On Tue, Mar 4, 2025 at 18:45 Marc Leavitt <leavitt@clemson.edu> wrote: Okay, so everything has to match to get full credit. I get that. What I don't get is receiving 0 credit for an extra word in the column header all of the other output matches. If that's the way it is, that's the way it is. I just want to verify that what I experienced (no credit) is the expected result. Thanks, From: Koushik Kumar Varma Nallaparaju <knallap@g.clemson.edu> Sent: Tuesday, March 4, 2025 3:41 PM To: Marc Leavitt <leavitt@clemson.edu> Cc: Connie Taylor <connie2@clemson.edu> Subject: Re: Grading on PracticeSet02-Problem04.sql (0/5) Hi Marc, Yes, you need to match the header as well, To get full credit on the SQL labs, You need to match the exact output. Best, Koushik. On Tue, Mar 4, 2025 at 6:30 PM Marc Leavitt <leavitt@clemson.edu> wrote: Koushik, I just submitted Module 07 SQL Lab - PracticeSet02 and was scored 0/5 on Problem 4. Here's the output from GradeScope on Problem 4: -------------------------- SUBMISSION ------------------------------------------- SELECT STAY.StayID, GUEST.GuestID, FORMAT(CEIL(ABS(STAY.StayPrice)),1) AS 'CEIL(ABS(STAY.StayPrice))' FROM STAY JOIN GUEST ON STAY.GuestID = GUEST.GuestID WHERE StayPrice < 0; -------------------------- SUBMISSION RESULTS ----------------------------------- +--------+---------+---------------------------+ | StayID | GuestID | CEIL(ABS(STAY.StayPrice)) | +--------+---------+---------------------------+ | 7 | 6 | 121.0 | | 12 | 3 | 131.0 | +--------+---------+---------------------------+ -------------------------- EXPECTED RESULTS ------------------------------------- +--------+---------+----------------------+ | StayID | GuestID | CEIL(ABS(StayPrice)) | +--------+---------+----------------------+ | 7 | 6 | 121.0 | | 12 | 3 | 131.0 | +--------+---------+----------------------+ --------------------------------------------------------------------------------- As far as I can tell, I was given a 0/5 because the 3rd column header was "CEIL(ABS(STAY.StayPrice))" instead of "CEIL(ABS(StayPrice))"? I.e., no credit because I used a table qualifier and it was pulled into the column header? Or was it something else? Thank you and sorry for the flurry of questions 😉 Marc

subject: Re: Questions on Project Part 1: Database Design
content: Yes, it should be rendered as shown in lectures! Best regards, Koushik. On Tue, Mar 11, 2025 at 13:27 Marc Leavitt <leavitt@clemson.edu> wrote: One follow-up question: Should the specialization hierarchy be rendered as demonstrated in the textbook and lectures or should it be rendered with adapted Crow's Foot notation? Thank you From: Connie Taylor <connie2@clemson.edu> Sent: Saturday, March 8, 2025 12:52 PM To: Marc Leavitt <leavitt@clemson.edu>; Koushik Kumar Varma Nallaparaju <knallap@g.clemson.edu>; Gary Matthew Webb <gmwebb@clemson.edu> Subject: Re: Questions on Project Part 1: Database Design Please see answers below. Koushik - please correct me or elaborate where needed. CONNIE TAYLOR Associate Director and Professor of Practice School of Computing, Clemson University o 864-656-5878 connie2@clemson.edu From: Marc Leavitt <leavitt@clemson.edu> Date: Friday, March 7, 2025 at 6:23 PM To: Koushik Kumar Varma Nallaparaju <knallap@g.clemson.edu>, Connie Taylor <connie2@clemson.edu>, Gary Matthew Webb <gmwebb@clemson.edu> Subject: Questions on Project Part 1: Database Design Koushik, My project partner (Gary Webb) and I are drafting the ERD and have compiled the following list of questions, in no particular order: Do rooms have a cost? Do schools?Are they required entities? I think the location field covers it. Do we need this?All you need is a class and class cost. Do assistant leaders have a cost? What if they're volunteers? Only the primary leader has the cost. Do sessions have a price? I.e., that non-leading students pay? If so, do assistant leaders have to pay? Not needed Do we need to document cardinality? (vs. connectivity) No, cardinality is not required to be documented, but implied from the ERD relationships. Are we okay expanding the student attributes? I.e., adding basic contact information? Sure. Extra attributes are fine. Do we need to describe levels in addition to naming them? I would describe them. The business rules mention "schools" and "rooms"—are schools important to location? Or should we just have "LOCATION" that has school and room identifiers? You can just specify the location as part of the class information but not needed as a separate entity. Do we need to track student class attendance history? You should have this information included in one of your entities. Do we need to track history of sessions/leaders? You should have this information included in one of your entities. Should we subclass 'LEADER' & use specialization hierarchy? Yes Is the assignment of leaders at a class level or session level? This is a design decision - document what you decide in the rational you are providing. Do we need to use the dependency diagram notations, EERM? The dependency diagram is unnecessary; however, you should think about your ERD and ensure it is in 3NF. Do we connect relationships at an entity or attribute level for the Relationships are always between entities ? Not sure I understand your question. connectors14) What does an A grade look like? What do we need to do to make it happen. ERD that meets the requirements and we can use rationale to validate your decisions. There are different ways to implement this. Do we need to track students' date of joining? Enroll date? Yes Please let us know if any of the questions need to be clarified. Thanks, Marc

subject: Re: Questions on the Design Rationale requirement for Project Part 1 submission
content: Hi Gary, I feel you should have the discriminator field, because it is the field that is distinguishing between the student and leader. Professor Taylor, correct me if I am wrong, I don't see any 3NF violation because. as the field is not having any transitive dependency with any other attribute in the table. Regarding expanding the hierarchy, If you want to you can increase it. But that is not mandatory to do so. From the image, make sure you use the correct distinguisher(disjoint/overlapping). Best, Koushik On Thu, Mar 13, 2025 at 7:30 PM Gary Matthew Webb <gmwebb@clemson.edu> wrote: Here is a drawing - the supertype discriminator field is in the orange box. From: Gary Matthew Webb <gmwebb@clemson.edu> Sent: Thursday, March 13, 2025 7:13 PM To: Marc Leavitt <leavitt@clemson.edu>; Koushik Kumar Varma Nallaparaju <knallap@g.clemson.edu> Cc: Connie Taylor <connie2@clemson.edu> Subject: Re: Questions on the Design Rationale requirement for Project Part 1 submission Hi team, We have another question regarding our subtype specialization hierarchy notation in the ERD. The guideline suggests we include a discriminator in the supertype, but we currently have a partial disjoint subtype (0..1) with supertype Student and subtype Leader. Adding a discriminator field "is_a_leader" to Student would break 3NF because that field would depend on the existence of a related record in the Leader table rather than solely on the student_id. In our design, if we want to designate a student as a leader, we insert a record into the Leader table and rely on the existence of that record (via the shared PK, FK). This avoids an extra CRUD operation and redundant data. If a student becomes a leader, I would have to do 2 operations: an update to Student.student_is_a_leader and an insert to the Leaders table. So, I have a few questions: Do you want us to add the discriminator field in the supertype anyway? Should we expand our subtype hierarchy by adding additional subtypes (e.g., volunteer, paid, and/or non-leader) and decide whether it should be partial or complete disjoint? Should we simply document this decision in the design rationale and not include a discriminator field in the Student table? Frankly, the 0..1 subtype setup makes my skin crawl because a subtype discriminator in the supertype it would force us into a 3NF violation—something I wouldn’t allow in a production environment. I'm leaning toward not adding the discriminator field and just explaining our rationale in the design documentation. What do you think? subject: Re: Questions on the Design Rationale requirement for Project Part 1 submission
content: Here is a drawing - the supertype discriminator field is in the orange box. From: Gary Matthew Webb <gmwebb@clemson.edu> Sent: Thursday, March 13, 2025 7:13 PM To: Marc Leavitt <leavitt@clemson.edu>; Koushik Kumar Varma Nallaparaju <knallap@g.clemson.edu> Cc: Connie Taylor <connie2@clemson.edu> Subject: Re: Questions on the Design Rationale requirement for Project Part 1 submission Hi team, We have another question regarding our subtype specialization hierarchy notation in the ERD. The guideline suggests we include a discriminator in the supertype, but we currently have a partial disjoint subtype (0..1) with supertype Student and subtype Leader. Adding a discriminator field "is_a_leader" to Student would break 3NF because that field would depend on the existence of a related record in the Leader table rather than solely on the student_id. In our design, if we want to designate a student as a leader, we insert a record into the Leader table and rely on the existence of that record (via the shared PK, FK). This avoids an extra CRUD operation and redundant data. If a student becomes a leader, I would have to do 2 operations: an update to Student.student_is_a_leader and an insert to the Leaders table. So, I have a few questions: Do you want us to add the discriminator field in the supertype anyway? Should we expand our subtype hierarchy by adding additional subtypes (e.g., volunteer, paid, and/or non-leader) and decide whether it should be partial or complete disjoint? Should we simply document this decision in the design rationale and not include a discriminator field in the Student table? Frankly, the 0..1 subtype setup makes my skin crawl because a subtype discriminator in the supertype it would force us into a 3NF violation—something I wouldn’t allow in a production environment. I'm leaning toward not adding the discriminator field and just explaining our rationale in the design documentation. What do you think? Thank you Gary Webb From: Marc Leavitt <leavitt@clemson.edu> Sent: Wednesday, March 12, 2025 2:07 PM To: Koushik Kumar Varma Nallaparaju <knallap@g.clemson.edu> Cc: Connie Taylor <connie2@clemson.edu>; Gary Matthew Webb <gmwebb@clemson.edu> Subject: Re: Questions on the Design Rationale requirement for Project Part 1 submission Perfect. Thanks! subject: Final Official Transcripts + Registration Update
content: Hi all, I have an update regarding the submission of Final Official Transcripts that may impact your registration next week. For Final Official Transcripts, you must submit these to Clemson’s Graduate School within your first semester of enrollment. If you do not, then there is a hold placed on your account that will prevent you from registering. You can check your account for this transcript hold (as well as other holds) by logging into iRoar > Student Self-Service > under Student Records header > Advising Student Profile. From here, you will see a notification for holds in the top, right corner. Any holds that will prevent registration should provide specific instructions on how to remove the hold, but if you have any questions or concerns about the holds, please let me know! If your undergraduate university is in the US and offers virtual transcripts, then it should only take a few days to receive the transcript and update your profile. However, if you must mail in your transcript, then this process may take a bit longer. The very good news is that there is no cap on our Coursera classes, so you are still guaranteed a seat, as long as we receive your transcript before the last day to add a class! If you haven’t already, I would recommend that you submit your transcript as soon as possible to avoid any delays. I do want to apologize as normally notifications go out to students throughout the semester with reminders about their final transcripts, but unfortunately, due to a technical error, these notifications were not going out. Additionally, I believe some of the language in the orientation module may have been misleading, and we are having that updated! Again, I sincerely apologize for any confusion or inconvenience. However, we can hopefully get everyone sorted before the start of the Spring semester! I’ve attached our Final Official Transcript procedures for your reference. Thank you all so much for your patience! With this being a new program, we might run into a few technical issues along the way, but we are so excited to have you all on board! We hope that you are enjoying the curriculum and are excited to continue in the program! Kind regards, Becca Spilka Graduate Services Coordinator School of Computing College of Engineering, Computing, and Applied Sciences

subject: CORRECTION: Colloquium Notice - CS PhD Dissertation Defense - Thomas Randall
content: Colloquium Notice Thomas Randall PhD Candidate, Computer Science Dissertation Defense Presentation Friday, April 11, 2025 at 12:30PM McAdams 106 Remote connection via https://clemson.zoom.us/j/99163737541 Title A Systemic Approach to Maximize Heterogeneous System Performance Abstract Continuous increases in high performance computing (HPC) throughput have served as catalysts for industry and scientific advancement in countless manners that have fundamentally shaped our modern world. Our demands on compute resources continue to scale, but the limitations of Ahmdal's law and Dennard scaling have proven increasingly difficult to overcome when approached solely through hardware or software design. Furthermore, even on the most advanced supercomputers, many HPC applications fail to utilize the collective system's performance. However, the resurgence of AI in industry has promoted an explosion of hardware and software codesign that have fueled massive improvements in GPU design and novel ASICs. These performance improvements are maximized on a broad variety of heterogeneous systems by specially tuning applications. Mimicking these developments across the whole of computing will require similarly holistic approaches combining specialty hardware, software that caters its design to the greatest strength of hardware, and fine-tuning on individual systems to truly maximize performance. In this work, we use three distinct perspectives to holistically address scalable system performance. We analyze the impacts of liquid immersion cooling technologies on sustained application performance and energy efficiency. Next, we present a case study where intentional algorithmic redesign for GPU acceleration permits robust performance improvements that endure through multiple generations of hardware. We find that memory latency forms a primary bottleneck for GPU-accelerated performance and demonstrate how algorithm-specific optimizations can greatly improve performance over multiple architecture generations. Finally, we tie these concepts together in the form of performance optimization techniques that respect both software- and hardware-based performance constraints. We improve the re-usability of performance insights with novel transfer learning techniques that make the cost of performance optimization more predictable and more successful in the short-term. Our insights demonstrate the necessity of systemic approaches for performance tuning in HPC. Committee Members: Dr. Rong Ge, School of Computing (committee chair); Dr. Prasanna Balaprakash, Oak Ridge National Laboratory; Dr. Kai Liu, School of Computing; Dr. Feng Luo, School of Computing; Dr. Xingfu Wu, Argonne National Laboratory

subject: Helpful Registration Information for Graduate Students – Summer and Fall 2025
content: Dear SoC Graduate Students, Registration for Summer 2025 and Fall 2025 will begin Monday, April 7 at 8:00am. Time Tickets will be assigned Monday, March 31. Please review the information below and attached. Time Tickets: Once time tickets are assigned, please consult iROAR for your registration time ticket (iROAR > Student Self-Service > Advising Student Profile > Registration Notices (top right corner)), mark your calendars, and register as soon as your registration window opens. If you do not have a time ticket please email cpscreg@clemson.edu. You can also use the Plan Ahead tool to plan your schedule ahead of time. If a desired course is full: Add yourself to the waitlist if one is available (see attached instructions). If a seat becomes available, the first person on the waitlist will receive an email and have 24 hours to register for the class or remove themselves from the waitlist. If no action is taken within 24 hours they’re dropped from the waitlist and the system contacts the next person on the list. Be sure to check your emails daily. If no waitlist is available, please submit a Request Closed Course form (see attached instructions). A request does NOT guarantee a seat. We will be reviewing them later in Spring. You will receive an email if we are able to add you to the course. DO NOT EMAIL THE CLASS INSTRUCTOR. Do not submit a CCR prior to your time ticket opening or it will NOT be considered. Keep checking iROAR as other students are continually adding/dropping classes and seats may open. Search for and register for an alternative course (especially if an elective). This is especially important for international graduate students on an F1 visa and any graduate student on assistantship. Both require a minimum of 9 credit hours per semester. If you’re able to get into your preferred course, you can drop the alternative course prior to the drop deadline without negative consequence. For an academic calendar listing the add/drop deadline, see https://www.clemson.edu/registrar/academic-calendars/. Duplicate or Repeat Course Errors: Please email cpscreg@clemson.edu with your full name, CID, and course subject, number, and section (CPSC 9910-001) and error message. Changing Variable Credits See Attached instructions Courses outside the School of Computing (Computer Science MS only): As a reminder, Computer Science MS students are allowed to take up to four pre-approved courses outside the School of Computing to apply toward their master's degree. These courses will count toward their overall credit-hour requirements and their 6000/8000-level credit-hour minimum/maximums, but they do not count toward their concentration and breadth requirements. A list of pre-approved courses for the Compute Science MS is attached to this email. If you are a Computer Science MS student and find a course outside the School of Computing that you are interested in that is not on this list, please email Chip Lang (hclang@clemson.edu). Important registration deadlines (add, drop, withdraw, etc.) can be found on the Academic Calendar at https://www.clemson.edu/registrar/academic-resources/academic-calendars.html. It is your responsibility to follow these deadlines to avoid additional fees (See https://www.clemson.edu/sfs/adjustments-refunds/adjustment-policy.html). Asking for Help: Contact your program coordinator or advisor for help choosing classes. iROAR Training manuals can be found at https://www.clemson.edu/registrar/registration-degreeworks/index.html Registration Coordinator cpscreg@clemson.edu School of Computing

subject: Student Account Statement Available
content: This is an automated message to inform you that an updated monthly student account statement is now available. To view this monthly student account statement, use your Clemson userid and password to log into iRoar (link below). Once logged in, access the "Student Billing" tab and select "My Bill". Pay your fees by e-check (no service fee) or by Visa, MasterCard, American Express or Discover (a 2.95% service fee applies to all domestic credit/debit cards, and a 4.25% service fee applies to all international credit/debit cards). ***Please note that this statement is a reflection of your student account activity as of today and will not reflect any changes made after this statement is released. However, you can always view your account balance in real-time by accessing your student account. In addition, for an updated statement at any time, you can click the "On Demand Statement" button in the Statement section on the home page of your student account. Payment Plan Enrollees: please log into iROAR to check your payment plan amounts and/or due dates. Current payment plans will show as no amount due on your monthly statement as they take into consideration your promise to pay on the designated due dates. In order to ensure timely posting of your payment, we strongly recommend that you make online payment via iROAR. Any "Amount Due" should be paid immediately. Any outstanding balance prevents registration for future terms and may be subject to a midterm billing fee of $75.00. If the "Amount Due" is a negative amount, a refund will be processed, and no payment is required at this time. Students are encouraged to setup an e-refund account by using the "Refunds" menu item at the top of their home page when accessing their student account. Please expect Summer 2025 bills to be available on Monday, April 21st. subject: Get started with the Figma Education plan
content: Here are a few resources to help you make the most out of Figma. &nb sp; Welcome to the Figma Education plan! We're so glad to have you. Here are a few resources to help you make the most out of Figma: Figma templates Figma connects everyone in the design process so teams can deliver better products, faster. These are some of our favorite templates to get started with Figma: Resume template: Easily create and update your resume in Figma. Portfolio examples: Get inspired by portfolios in the Figma Community. Feedback and critique template: Facilitate constructive feedback from teachers and peers. FigJam templates FigJam is an online whiteboard for teams to brainstorm and ideate together. These templates will help you start jamming on your next project faster: Diagramming basics: Build your next flow chart with flexible connectors and shortcuts. User research resources: Easily create user personas and consolidate research findings. Mood boarding activity: Create fun mood boards before starting your next project. Explore all templates That's all for now. We're here if you get stuck or have questions. :) Figma is a design platform for teams who build products together. Born on the Web, Figma helps the entire product team create, test, and ship better designs, faster. 760 Market Street, Floor 10 San Francisco, CA, 94102 Unsubscribe from Figma marketing emails.
