subject: Re: Questions on the Design Rationale requirement for Project Part 1 submission
content: Hi team, We have another question regarding our subtype specialization hierarchy notation in the ERD. The guideline suggests we include a discriminator in the supertype, but we currently have a partial disjoint subtype (0..1) with supertype Student and subtype Leader. Adding a discriminator field "is_a_leader" to Student would break 3NF because that field would depend on the existence of a related record in the Leader table rather than solely on the student_id. In our design, if we want to designate a student as a leader, we insert a record into the Leader table and rely on the existence of that record (via the shared PK, FK). This avoids an extra CRUD operation and redundant data. If a student becomes a leader, I would have to do 2 operations: an update to Student.student_is_a_leader and an insert to the Leaders table. So, I have a few questions: Do you want us to add the discriminator field in the supertype anyway? Should we expand our subtype hierarchy by adding additional subtypes (e.g., volunteer, paid, and/or non-leader) and decide whether it should be partial or complete disjoint? Should we simply document this decision in the design rationale and not include a discriminator field in the Student table? Frankly, the 0..1 subtype setup makes my skin crawl because a subtype discriminator in the supertype it would force us into a 3NF violation—something I wouldn’t allow in a production environment. I'm leaning toward not adding the discriminator field and just explaining our rationale in the design documentation. What do you think? Thank you Gary Webb From: Marc Leavitt <leavitt@clemson.edu> Sent: Wednesday, March 12, 2025 2:07 PM To: Koushik Kumar Varma Nallaparaju <knallap@g.clemson.edu> Cc: Connie Taylor <connie2@clemson.edu>; Gary Matthew Webb <gmwebb@clemson.edu> Subject: Re: Questions on the Design Rationale requirement for Project Part 1 submission Perfect. Thanks! From: Koushik Kumar Varma Nallaparaju <knallap@g.clemson.edu> Sent: Wednesday, March 12, 2025 11:05 AM To: Marc Leavitt <leavitt@clemson.edu> Cc: Connie Taylor <connie2@clemson.edu>; Gary Matthew Webb <gmwebb@clemson.edu> Subject: Re: Questions on the Design Rationale requirement for Project Part 1 submission Hi Marc, Yes, the design rationale is due with the ERD. You need to submit a single merged PDF of both ERD and design rationale. (see additional doc for details) It is a reference to the paragraph at the end of the assignment document. Best, Koushik. On Wed, Mar 12, 2025 at 1:58 PM Marc Leavitt <leavitt@clemson.edu> wrote: Just to make sure we're not missing anything: I believe that the design rationale is due with the ERD on 3/16 (zipped PDFs, etc). Please confirm or deny. At the end of the 10th item in the requirements section (the one that first mentions the design rationale document), it says "(see additional doc for details)"—are there additional documents or is this just a reference to the paragraph at the end of the assignment document (pasted below for reference)? ---------------- Design Rationale: This rationale is a brief description (1-2 pages max) of your reasoning in the design process. You should discuss the entities you created and their relationships, citing specific business rules (they are numbered to may this easy). This information is particularly useful for the bridge entities you create and any historical data tables. Pay particular attention to any discriminators that you include in your design. ---------------- Thanks, Marc

subject: Re: Questions on Project Part 1: Database Design
content: Please see answers below. Koushik - please correct me or elaborate where needed. CONNIE TAYLOR Associate Director and Professor of Practice School of Computing, Clemson University o 864-656-5878 connie2@clemson.edu From: Marc Leavitt <leavitt@clemson.edu> Date: Friday, March 7, 2025 at 6:23 PM To: Koushik Kumar Varma Nallaparaju <knallap@g.clemson.edu>, Connie Taylor <connie2@clemson.edu>, Gary Matthew Webb <gmwebb@clemson.edu> Subject: Questions on Project Part 1: Database Design Koushik, My project partner (Gary Webb) and I are drafting the ERD and have compiled the following list of questions, in no particular order: Do rooms have a cost? Do schools? Are they required entities? I think the location field covers it. Do we need this? All you need is a class and class cost. Do assistant leaders have a cost? What if they're volunteers? Only the primary leader has the cost. Do sessions have a price? I.e., that non-leading students pay? If so, do assistant leaders have to pay? Not needed Do we need to document cardinality? (vs. connectivity) No, cardinality is not required to be documented, but implied from the ERD relationships. Are we okay expanding the student attributes? I.e., adding basic contact information? Sure. Extra attributes are fine. Do we need to describe levels in addition to naming them? I would describe them. The business rules mention "schools" and "rooms"—are schools important to location? Or should we just have "LOCATION" that has school and room identifiers? You can just specify the location as part of the class information but not needed as a separate entity. Do we need to track student class attendance history? You should have this information included in one of your entities. Do we need to track history of sessions/leaders? You should have this information included in one of your entities. Should we subclass 'LEADER' & use specialization hierarchy? Yes Is the assignment of leaders at a class level or session level? This is a design decision - document what you decide in the rational you are providing. Do we need to use the dependency diagram notations, EERM? The dependency diagram is unnecessary; however, you should think about your ERD and ensure it is in 3NF. Do we connect relationships at an entity or attribute level for the Relationships are always between entities ? Not sure I understand your question. connectors 14) What does an A grade look like? What do we need to do to make it happen. ERD that meets the requirements and we can use rationale to validate your decisions. There are different ways to implement this. Do we need to track students' date of joining? Enroll date? Yes Please let us know if any of the questions need to be clarified. Thanks, Marc

subject: Re: Questions on Project Part 1: Database Design
content: I would suggest you to follow the naming conventions. It is ok to use either of the CusBalance/Cus_Balance but make sure the attribute is meaningful. Best regards, Koushik. On Tue, Mar 11, 2025 at 18:11 Marc Leavitt <leavitt@clemson.edu> wrote: Koushik, I would like to promise you that this is the last question, but I don't think either of us would believe that 😉 Does the attribute naming that we adopt impact grading? I.e., in the examples that I've seen (and remembered) from lecture and/or the textbook, attribute names were either snake/upper case or camel/lowercase AND the attribute name has reflected the entity in which it was defined (e.g., 'CUS_BALANCE' or 'CusBalance'. If we use attribute names that are snake/lowercase (e.g., "cus_balance"), is that a problem? If our attribute names do not reflect the table names (e.g., just "balance"), is that a problem? Does that question makes sense? Thanks, Marc From: Koushik Kumar Varma Nallaparaju <knallap@g.clemson.edu> Sent: Tuesday, March 11, 2025 11:01 AM To: Gary Matthew Webb <gmwebb@clemson.edu> Cc: Marc Leavitt <leavitt@clemson.edu>; Connie Taylor <connie2@clemson.edu> Subject: Re: Questions on Project Part 1: Database Design You should include the circle with the required symbol inside it along with the completeness as well. Best, Koushik. On Tue, Mar 11, 2025 at 1:37 PM Gary Matthew Webb <gmwebb@clemson.edu> wrote: We are trying to figure out if we should show the circle with a "d" inside of it style notation or if basic crowsfoot is ok to model the subtype. The attached photo shows what it looks like with basic crowsfoot. I don't have a picture of the EER style subtype because I regrettably changed it. Get Outlook for Android From: Koushik Kumar Varma Nallaparaju <knallap@g.clemson.edu> Sent: Tuesday, March 11, 2025 1:29:30 PM To: Marc Leavitt <leavitt@clemson.edu> Cc: Connie Taylor <connie2@clemson.edu>; Gary Matthew Webb <gmwebb@clemson.edu> Subject: Re: Questions on Project Part 1: Database Design Yes, it should be rendered as shown in lectures! Best regards, Koushik. On Tue, Mar 11, 2025 at 13:27 Marc Leavitt <leavitt@clemson.edu> wrote: One follow-up question: Should the specialization hierarchy be rendered as demonstrated in the textbook and lectures or should it be rendered with adapted Crow's Foot notation? Thank you From: Connie Taylor <connie2@clemson.edu> Sent: Saturday, March 8, 2025 12:52 PM To: Marc Leavitt <leavitt@clemson.edu>; Koushik Kumar Varma Nallaparaju <knallap@g.clemson.edu>; Gary Matthew Webb <gmwebb@clemson.edu> Subject: Re: Questions on Project Part 1: Database Design Please see answers below. Koushik - please correct me or elaborate where needed. CONNIE TAYLOR Associate Director and Professor of Practice School of Computing, Clemson University o 864-656-5878 connie2@clemson.edu From: Marc Leavitt <leavitt@clemson.edu> Date: Friday, March 7, 2025 at 6:23 PM To: Koushik Kumar Varma Nallaparaju <knallap@g.clemson.edu>, Connie Taylor <connie2@clemson.edu>, Gary Matthew Webb <gmwebb@clemson.edu> Subject: Questions on Project Part 1: Database Design Koushik, My project partner (Gary Webb) and I are drafting the ERD and have compiled the following list of questions, in no particular order: Do rooms have a cost? Do schools?Are they required entities? I think the location field covers it. Do we need this?All you need is a class and class cost. Do assistant leaders have a cost? What if they're volunteers? Only the primary leader has the cost. Do sessions have a price? I.e., that non-leading students pay? If so, do assistant leaders have to pay? Not needed Do we need to document cardinality? (vs. connectivity) No, cardinality is not required to be documented, but implied from the ERD relationships. Are we okay expanding the student attributes? I.e., adding basic contact information? Sure. Extra attributes are fine. Do we need to describe levels in addition to naming them? I would describe them. The business rules mention "schools" and "rooms"—are schools important to location? Or should we just have "LOCATION" that has school and room identifiers? You can just specify the location as part of the class information but not needed as a separate entity. Do we need to track student class attendance history? You should have this information included in one of your entities. Do we need to track history of sessions/leaders? You should have this information included in one of your entities. Should we subclass 'LEADER' & use specialization hierarchy? Yes Is the assignment of leaders at a class level or session level? This is a design decision - document what you decide in the rational you are providing. Do we need to use the dependency diagram notations, EERM? The dependency diagram is unnecessary; however, you should think about your ERD and ensure it is in 3NF. Do we connect relationships at an entity or attribute level for the Relationships are always between entities ? Not sure I understand your question. connectors14) What does an A grade look like? What do we need to do to make it happen. ERD that meets the requirements and we can use rationale to validate your decisions. There are different ways to implement this. Do we need to track students' date of joining? Enroll date? Yes Please let us know if any of the questions need to be clarified. Thanks, Marc

subject: Spring Academic Calendar Reminders
content: Hi all, Some important reminders for you as begin your Spring Semester! Adding/dropping classes: The last day to add a class is Tuesday, January 14th. We will not be able to add you to a class after this date, so please solidify your schedule before this date. The last day to drop a class is Wednesday, January 22nd. If you drop a class after this date, the course will show on your transcript with a W. The last day to drop a class without a final grade is Friday, March 14th. Keep in mind that these dates vary for courses that are not the full Spring term. All dates can be found on the Academic Calendar, here: https://www.clemson.edu/registrar/academic-calendars/index.html. For students who are part-time (less than 9 credit hours), keep in mind the dates for adjustments to Academic Fees when you drop a class. The last day to drop a class without a charge to your bill is Wednesday, January 22nd. These dates also vary for courses that are not on the full Spring term, so I recommend reviewing this page: https://www.clemson.edu/finance/student-financials/adjustments/. If you have any questions about your bill, you can reach out to Student Financial Services at studentbillquestions@clemson.edu. For Spring 2025 graduates, you can go ahead and apply to graduate in iRoar under Student Self-Service. You must have an approved GS2 Plan of Study on file to apply to graduate, so if you have not already completed that, you should do so immediately. The deadline to apply to graduate is Wednesday, January 29th. After this date, you will incur a fee for each day the application is late. If you have any other questions, let me know! Best, Chip Lang Graduate Services Coordinator School of Computing College of Engineering, Computing and Applied Sciences hclang@clemson.edu

subject: Clemson Board of Trustees first 2025 quarterly meeting focuses on University’s impact
content: FEBRUARY 7, 2025 Board of Trustees first 2025 quarterly meeting focuses on University’s impact With an overarching focus on the third pillar of Clemson Elevate — the impact of Clemson University to transform lives across the state of South Carolina and beyond — the 2025 Winter Quarterly Meeting of the Clemson Board of Trustees was held February 4-7. During committee meetings over two days and a full board meeting on Friday, February 7, the Board received updates from Clemson President James P. Clements and senior University leadership about ongoing research, education, student support, fundraising and statewide outreach. STUDENTS Doug Hallenbeck, vice president of student affairs, provided the Board with an update on the Division of Student Affairs’ efforts to enhance the student experience, preparing students for lives of leadership, service and significance. Hallenbeck highlighted both the division’s work in support of the academic mission alongside a focus on mental and physical well-being and recreation. President Clements customarily highlights a student at each of his quarterly updates to the Board, and spotlighted the achievements of Adam Gatch, a biochemistry honors student from Charleston. Gatch was recently named a Churchill Scholar, one of only 16 students nationwide to receive the award, which covers one year of master’s study at the University of Cambridge. Gatch’s achievement makes Clemson the only university whose students have been awarded a Churchill Scholarship in each of the last three years. Gatch plans to pursue a Master of Philosophy in chemistry and work with Professor Tuomas Knowles at the Centre for Misfolding Diseases, a leading research center dedicated to understanding the abnormal behavior of proteins in the brain in neurodegenerative disorders, such as Alzheimer’s and Parkinson’s disease. RESEARCH Tanju Karanfil, senior vice president for research, scholarship and creative endeavors, highlighted the substantial growth of Clemson’s research enterprise: Total research and development expenditures topped $300 million for the first time at $334 million in 2024, more than double that of 2013. During the fiscal year, Clemson graduated 324 Ph.D. students, an increase of 73 percent since 2013. As 2025 began, Clemson had 2,048 active research projects with a total budget amount of more than $823 million – a nearly 70 percent increase in the number of active projects over the past decade, and the combined value of those projects has more than tripled. Dr. Karanfil also recognized faculty members Ronnie Chowdhury and Cheng Sun for earning rare presidential awards from the U.S. government. Dr. Karanfil also provided numerous examples of Clemson transforming lives through research. Senior Vice President for External Affairs Angie Leidinger provided an overview of the University’s state budget priorities for FY25-26, which includes funding for tuition mitigation, a NextGen Computing Complex, the Clemson Center for Human Genetics, as well as support for several Public Service Activities priorities. Leidinger provided updates on the President’s Industry Council, corporate engagement activity and innovation campus strategy. Current and former students joined Arthrex Vice President of Communications and President’s Industry Council member Dennis O’Keefe and Executive Director of the Sales Innovation Program (SIP) at Clemson and Professor of Marketing Ryan Mullins to highlight the impact of SIP, both on the student experience and industry partnerships. Arthrex, a global medical device company, offers scholarships through the Arthrex Sales Innovation Scholars program to Clemson students and collaborates regularly with University research faculty and administration to advance mutually beneficial goals and meet the state’s economic goals in meaningful ways. ACADEMICS Provost Bob Jones provided updates on undergraduate admissions and longer-term enrollment trends, distance education strategies to generate new revenues and broaden the University’s reach, and Clemson Elevate metrics including a new Extension activities index. Dean Leslie Hossfeld provided an update on the impressive work of the College of Behavioral, Social and Health Sciences and its direct work transforming lives through improving health outcomes, meeting workforce demands and supporting rural communities across South Carolina. Action items from the Educational Policy Committee included the creation of several programs and centers: New M.S. in Statistics and Data Science New Ph.D. in Statistics and Data Science New Center for Community Engagement Research New Center for Roofing Innovation and Leadership (CRIL) New Center for Safety, Health & Ergonomics Research for Performance Augmentation (SHERPA) New Trilith Institute Instructional Site Name change of the Center for Criminal Justice and Social Research to the Center for Public Safety Research FINANCE AND FACILITIES The Board received an update to the University’s long range framework plan revised to align with the strategic plan and pillars of Clemson Elevate. The administration also provided a mid-year financial update while revisiting first quarter financials and the steps the University has taken since October 2024. The Board of Trustees approved the following facility projects: New lease for space in Greenville on the CU-ICAR Campus for College of Engineering, Computing and Applied Sciences to accommodate faculty/student offices, teaching labs, and research space in support of the new Bachelor of Science degree in Automotive Engineering as well as research and teaching spaces for the School of Computing and Industrial Engineering. An update to the Clemson University Fire Department fire station following construction and widening of Perimeter Road. FUTURE MEETINGS The next quarterly meeting of Clemson’s Board of Trustees is scheduled to be held in Clemson April 23-25, 2025. subject: Re: Questions on Final Project Part 2
content: Even I am not sure, which one is running first! On Fri, Apr 4, 2025 at 20:03 Marc Leavitt <leavitt@clemson.edu> wrote: I can confirm that enabling the triggers before running PopulateData.sql logically corrupts the data From: Marc Leavitt <leavitt@clemson.edu> Sent: Friday, April 4, 2025 4:53 PM To: Koushik Kumar Varma Nallaparaju <knallap@g.clemson.edu> Cc: Connie Taylor <connie2@clemson.edu>; Gary Matthew Webb <gmwebb@clemson.edu> Subject: Re: Questions on Final Project Part 2 Sorry Koushik, but I'm still confused on the triggers. If they are enabled, so let me lay this out carefully. I have triggers on insert and update of pizza_topping, pizza_discount, and order_discount (and yes, the triggers use stored functions) that update pizza and order prices+costs (incl discounts) If the triggers are enabled while the autograder is populating any of those 3 tables (), there's a pretty good chance that the price and cost of the pizza and/or order is going to be set wrong In the autograder environment, I don't have control over when the triggers are enabled In my local environment, I address this by not enabling the triggers (and functions and SPs) until after the non-transactional tables (customer, discount, baseprice, topping) are populated. Then I run a local script (not submitted to not confuse the autograder) that use the stored automation and triggers to populate ordertable, order_discount, pizza, pizza_discount, and pizza_topping. This works great in my local environment I thought this was in-line with our previous email, but we're concerned that the triggers get executed at the wrong time and cause the grader to fail tests Questions: Have I made the concern clear? Is it okay to have triggers changing order and pizza price & cost? IMPORTANT: My partner (Gary) is super-jammed tonight, but he has been handling the submissions for our team. Can I take over doing submissions for our team tonight? Thanks & sorry, I thought this was in-the-can several hours ago. From: Koushik Kumar Varma Nallaparaju <knallap@g.clemson.edu> Sent: Thursday, April 3, 2025 9:22 AM To: Marc Leavitt <leavitt@clemson.edu> Cc: Connie Taylor <connie2@clemson.edu>; Gary Matthew Webb <gmwebb@clemson.edu> Subject: Re: Questions on Final Project Part 2 Hi Marc, 1. For now, yes. They shouldn’t need to modify the topping inventory. They are already deducted and given to you. You need to apply order discounts. Pizza discount is applied and given to you! 2. They will be executed and manually verified as well! 3. You can use them! Best, Koushik. On Wed, Apr 2, 2025 at 23:50 Marc Leavitt <leavitt@clemson.edu> wrote: A short list this time: Does "You do not need to deduct from the inventory for these orders (it has already been taken into account)" effectively mean that our SPs and functions should not modify topping inventory? More generally, will the autograder execute our triggers, SPs, and functions? Or is that more of a manual grading step? Just trying to think about autograder compliations… Should we be implementing CASCADEs on e.g., deletion of a pizza or an order? Or is this a bad idea? Thanks, Marc

I simply went with creating tables without any FKs first, rather than following the 1:M relationships around the ERD, which is a pattern that you have to break when you get to 'Treatment_Apt' anyway. I don't know if it's intentional or not but I'm pretty sure the key designations for 'Treatment_Apt' are incorrect—I think TREATMENT_ID & APPOINTMENT_ID are both attributes of a composite PK and also that they are both independently FKs In Treatment, TREATMENT_ID is both misspelled ('TREAMENT_ID', i.e., missing the second 'T'), and mislabeled as an FK The third answer option is missing a comma between 'Pet' and 'Appointments' Thank you

subject: Coursera Spring 2025 - Welcome & Academic Calendar Reminders
content: Hi all, Happy first day of classes! We are excited to have you all joining the online program, continuing the program, or just taking a few classes! You should have access to the Coursera platform at this point, and you should be completing the orientation course and/or begin to see your course content become available during this week. If you recently registered, it may take a day or two before the course appears on the Coursera platform. If you haven’t registered, please make sure to do so as soon as possible and before the last day to add. Some Academic Calendar reminders: The last day to add a class is Tuesday, January 14th. The last day to drop a class is Wednesday, January 22nd. If you drop a class after this date, the course will show on your transcript with a W. The last day to drop a class without a final grade is Friday, March 14th. All these dates (and more) can be found on the Academic Calendar, here: https://www.clemson.edu/registrar/academic-calendars/index.html. Koushik - please correct me or elaborate where needed. CONNIE TAYLOR Associate Director and Professor of Practice School of Computing, Clemson University o 864-656-5878 connie2@clemson.edu From: Marc Leavitt <leavitt@clemson.edu> Date: Friday, March 7, 2025 at 6:23 PM To: Koushik Kumar Varma Nallaparaju <knallap@g.clemson.edu>, Connie Taylor <connie2@clemson.edu>, Gary Matthew Webb <gmwebb@clemson.edu> Subject: Questions on Project Part 1: Database Design Koushik, My project partner (Gary Webb) and I are drafting the ERD and have compiled the following list of questions, in no particular order: Do rooms have a cost? Do schools?Are they required entities? I think the location field covers it. Do we need this?All you need is a class and class cost. Do assistant leaders have a cost? What if they're volunteers? Only the primary leader has the cost. Do sessions have a price? I.e., that non-leading students pay? If so, do assistant leaders have to pay? Not needed Do we need to document cardinality? (vs. connectivity) No, cardinality is not required to be documented, but implied from the ERD relationships. Are we okay expanding the student attributes? I.e., adding basic contact information? Sure. Extra attributes are fine. Do we need to describe levels in addition to naming them? I would describe them. The business rules mention "schools" and "rooms"—are schools important to location? Or should we just have "LOCATION" that has school and room identifiers? You can just specify the location as part of the class information but not needed as a separate entity. Do we need to track student class attendance history? You should have this information included in one of your entities. Do we need to track history of sessions/leaders? You should have this information included in one of your entities. Should we subclass 'LEADER' & use specialization hierarchy? Yes Is the assignment of leaders at a class level or session level? This is a design decision - document what you decide in the rational you are providing. Do we need to use the dependency diagram notations, EERM? The dependency diagram is unnecessary; however, you should think about your ERD and ensure it is in 3NF. Do we connect relationships at an entity or attribute level for the Relationships are always between entities ? Not sure I understand your question. connectors14) What does an A grade look like? What do we need to do to make it happen. ERD that meets the requirements and we can use rationale to validate your decisions. There are different ways to implement this. Do we need to track students' date of joining? Enroll date? Yes Please let us know if any of the questions need to be clarified. Thanks, Marc

subject: FW: Colloquium Notice - CS MS Thesis Defense - Austin Hartley
content: Colloquium Notice Austin Hartley M.S. Candidate, Computer Science Thesis Defense Presentation Wednesday, April 9, 2025 at 3:30 PM McAdams 110E Title Divergence-Free Smoothed Particle Hydrodynamics in a Stream Digital Twin Abstract Digital Twins (DT) are being used by the South Carolina (SC) water community to simulate how SC streams will flow at various water levels. Currently, a DT called Gilligan simulates these streams utilizing weakly-incompressible Smoothed Particle Hydrodynamics (SPH). This method does not strictly enforce incompressibility, which leads to unrealistic water flows and unwanted visual artifacts that require post-processing effects to hide. To address these problems and simulate more realistic water flows, the Gilligan stream logic is updated and a state-of-the-art SPH method that enforces incompressibility—Divergence-Free SPH (DFSPH)—is implemented within the Gilligan framework. DFSPH is able to make use of two pressure solvers, one to ensure the fluid stays at constant density and another to keep the velocity field divergence free. Simulations are tested using a model of Hunnicutt Creek on the campus of Clemson University, showcasing the DFSPH water flows as being more realistic, detailed, and not requiring the same visual alterations to hide artifacts compared to the weakly-incompressible SPH Committee Members: Dr. Jerry Tessendorf, School of Computing (committee chair); Dr. Daljit Dhillon, School of Computing; Dr Matias Volonte, School of Computing.

subject: What do we love most about Anvil?
content: A few of our favorite things Hi there!I hope you’ve been enjoying Anvil so far! There’s a lot to take in and explore, so I thought I’d ask some of my colleagues to name their favorite thing about Anvil. "You can get something up and running on the web with no setup time" - Ian, Co-FounderIt was hard for Ian to pick just one thing, but I think he's biased! Learn more about cloud deployment "I like that you can connect to data sources and make some really powerful apps" - Patricia, Developer AdvocatePatricia even wrote a tutorial on building a dashboard using `pandas` and data from Netflix. Learn how to build a web app with Pandas "You can connect to code running anywhere. That really sets Anvil apart." - Ryan, Developer AdvocateThat code can be running anywhere from a Raspberry Pi to a Google Colab notebok. Build an app from a Google Colab notebook "I like that I can be a web developer without using JavaScript" - Brooke (Me!), Developer AdvocateI never considered myself a web developer before Anvil. But now I can even build web apps with JS libraries still using only Python. Watch me live code a Mapbox app I hope you find a lot to love about Anvil! All the best, Brooke Developer AdvocatePS: Have a question about using Anvil? The Anvil Community Forum is the best place to go for help. View this email online Follow us on Twitter: @anvil_works Click here to unsubscribe from all Anvil email.

subject: 2024 1098-T Taxpayer ID Request
content: Each January, Clemson University prepares the annual 1098-T Tuition Statement for students with qualified tuition and fees and scholarships/grants during the previous tax year. Form 1098-T contains information about qualified tuition and related expenses to help determine whether you, or the person who can claim you as a dependent, may take either the tuition and fees deduction or claim an education credit to reduce Federal income tax. For more information, see IRS Pub. 970, Tax Benefits for Higher Education at www.irs.gov. In preparation of the 2024 1098-T Statement, we have determined that Clemson University does not have a Social Security Number/Individual Taxpayer Identification number on file in your student record. Please click below to complete the on-line form and upload your social security card, if applicable, no later than January 15, 2025. Request for Student’s Taxpayer Identification Number This will help us ensure that we are accurately reporting your qualified tuition expenses and scholarships/grants so you can take advantage of any applicable tax benefits. Please note that failure to furnish a correct SSN/TIN could result in a penalty of up to $50 (per section 6109 IRS code) and may affect the Internal Revenue Service’s ability to confirm your eligibility for certain education tax benefits. Note to students with no SSN/TIN: If you do not have a Social Security Number/Individual Taxpayer Identification Number, you will still need to complete the on-line form.

subject: RE: Student Profile Hold Status for Spring 2025 Reg
content: Hi Marc, Thanks for reaching out and congratulations on passing the PBA courses! I'm working with the Grad Admissions team to make sure the process to get your record switched over from non-degree PBA to MSCS. At that point, the hold can be removed from your account. We were hoping to have these updates completed today, but it appears there may be a delay. I will follow up with more information before the end of the day! Clemson University is closed for winter break Monday, Dec 23rd through Friday, Dec 27th as well as New Year’s Day, Wednesday, Jan 1st. These closures include all University offices, except CCIT who will operate on adjusted holiday hours listed below. Clemson University will be operating on normal business hours Monday, Dec 30th and Tuesday, Dec 31st. All normal operations will resume Thursday, Jan 2nd. Please keep in mind that Clemson’s normal business hours are Monday to Friday 8:00AM – 4:30PM ET. If you are in need of immediate technical assistance, you can reach out to CCIT at ITHelp@clemson.edu, or visit their website. Adjusted holiday hours for CCIT are listed below: 12/21-12/22: 12PM-4PM 12/23-12/24: 10AM-4PM 12/25: Closed 12/26-12/27: 10AM-4PM 12/28-12/29: 12PM-4PM 12/30-12/31: 10AM-4PM 01/01: Closed Web resources are listed below for commonly asked questions. Program Overview: Clemson MSCS on Coursera Admissions: Graduate Admissions for Coursera Tuition/Billing: Student Financial Services Any remaining questions can be answered by our staff when they return on Thursday, Jan 2nd. Happy holidays! Danny Coursera Support Team | Degrees + Certificates --------------- Original Message --------------- From: Marc Leavitt [leavitt@clemson.edu] Sent: 12/19/2024, 11:38 AM To: mscscoursera@clemson.edu Subject: Re: Student Profile Hold Status for Spring 2025 Reg Becca, My grades are posted on iRoar, but there is still a hold on my registration for spring semester. Is there something I should do? Thanks, Marc ________________________________ From: MSCS Coursera <mscscoursera@clemson.edu> Sent: Thursday, November 14, 2024 7:16 AM Subject: Student Profile Hold Status for Spring 2025 Reg Hi all, I’m reaching out with an update regarding your student profile status and Spring registration. We were recently notified by CCIT that for students who are in both of the PBA courses will have a hold on their account that reads as “Non-degree to degree Hold”. The reason for this is that after grades are released, if you make a B or better in both courses, then an automatic process will be triggered in iRoar to update your student account from non-degree/PBA to Computer Science MS. If you are registered for Spring 2025 classes when this process is triggered, it will block the process from being completed. In order to avoid anyone’s account from getting stuck, we have placed a registration hold until after grades are released. If you do not see the hold, we may still be in the process of getting it added. Please do not register for Spring courses, as we will ask that you drop them. After grades are released, if you pass both courses with a B or better, then your account will be updated and this hold will be removed, and you can register for Spring courses. If for any reason you don't pass the PBA courses, the hold will still be removed, and we can always discuss possible paths forward! There are no course caps, so don’t worry about not securing a seat in the Spring courses. Once you register, bills will be automatically generated, and payments will be due Jan 2, 2025. If you have any questions, please don’t hesitate to reach out! Kind regards, Becca Spilka Graduate Services Coordinator School of Computing College of Engineering, Computing, and Applied Sciences [signature_1757566267]<https://www.clemson.edu/> thread::Aron1tpFEVeYmTVC07dvMh8::

subject: Re: Questions on Final Project Part 2
content: I am not completely sure, It is ok to change the data pizza price, order price. But they should match the output as expected by autograder On Fri, Apr 4, 2025 at 19:53 Marc Leavitt <leavitt@clemson.edu> wrote: Sorry Koushik, but I'm still confused on the triggers. If they are enabled, so let me lay this out carefully. I have triggers on insert and update of pizza_topping, pizza_discount, and order_discount (and yes, the triggers use stored functions) that update pizza and order prices+costs (incl discounts) If the triggers are enabled while the autograder is populating any of those 3 tables (), there's a pretty good chance that the price and cost of the pizza and/or order is going to be set wrong In the autograder environment, I don't have control over when the triggers are enabled In my local environment, I address this by not enabling the triggers (and functions and SPs) until after the non-transactional tables (customer, discount, baseprice, topping) are populated. Then I run a local script (not submitted to not confuse the autograder) that use the stored automation and triggers to populate ordertable, order_discount, pizza, pizza_discount, and pizza_topping. This works great in my local environment I thought this was in-line with our previous email, but we're concerned that the triggers get executed at the wrong time and cause the grader to fail tests Questions: Have I made the concern clear? Is it okay to have triggers changing order and pizza price & cost? IMPORTANT: My partner (Gary) is super-jammed tonight, but he has been handling the submissions for our team. Can I take over doing submissions for our team tonight? Thanks & sorry, I thought this was in-the-can several hours ago. From: Koushik Kumar Varma Nallaparaju <knallap@g.clemson.edu> Sent: Thursday, April 3, 2025 9:22 AM To: Marc Leavitt <leavitt@clemson.edu> Cc: Connie Taylor <connie2@clemson.edu>; Gary Matthew Webb <gmwebb@clemson.edu> Subject: Re: Questions on Final Project Part 2 Hi Marc, 1. For now, yes. They shouldn’t need to modify the topping inventory. They are already deducted and given to you. You need to apply order discounts. Pizza discount is applied and given to you! 2. They will be executed and manually verified as well! 3. You can use them! Best, Koushik. On Wed, Apr 2, 2025 at 23:50 Marc Leavitt <leavitt@clemson.edu> wrote: A short list this time: Does "You do not need to deduct from the inventory for these orders (it has already been taken into account)" effectively mean that our SPs and functions should not modify topping inventory? More generally, will the autograder execute our triggers, SPs, and functions? Or is that more of a manual grading step? Just trying to think about autograder compliations… Should we be implementing CASCADEs on e.g., deletion of a pizza or an order? Or is this a bad idea? Thanks, Marc

subject: RE: Important Upcoming Dates
content: Hi all, I wanted to send an update that the last day with withdraw without a final grade has been extended to Monday, Nov 4th. This extension was in response to the possible delay in midterm grades due to Hurricane Helene. You can find the updated date reflected on the Academic calendar for Fall 2024 here. Hope you all have a good weekend! Regards, Becca Spilka Graduate Services Coordinator School of Computing College of Engineering, Computing, and Applied Sciences From: MSCS Coursera Sent: Tuesday, October 22, 2024 12:03 PM Subject: Important Upcoming Dates Hi all, I am emailing to remind you of some important upcoming dates. First, the last day to withdraw from classes without a final grade is Monday, Oct 28th. This window ends at 11:59pm ET, so if you feel you may need to withdraw from a class, you need to do so before that date/time in order to not receive a final grade. The course will still appear on your transcript; however, your grade would show a “W” and does not impact your GPA. After this date/time, you will receive a final grade for the course. Second, registration for the Spring 2025 semester begins on Wednesday, November 6th at 8am ET. We will be offering both of the PBA courses (CPSC 8400 and 8740) in the Spring, and we will also be adding CPSC 6300, CPSC 6620, and HCC 6600 to the courses available through Coursera. If you have any questions about withdrawing or registration, please let me know by sending an email to mscscoursera@clemson.edu. Kind regards, Becca Spilka Graduate Services Coordinator School of Computing College of Engineering, Computing, and Applied Sciences

subject: Colloquium Notice - CS PhD Dissertation Defense - Jessica Baron-Lis
content: Colloquium Notice Jessica Baron-Lis PhD Candidate, Computer Science Dissertation Defense Presentation Tuesday, April 8, 2025 at 2:00PM McAdams 106 Remote connection via https://clemson.zoom.us/j/92279331472?pwd=Bd0hDPR0U4gYaq7JaVax82cjOaCc5M.1 passcode: 144172 Title A System and Method for Measuring Spatially Varying Surface Appearances with a Study of Feathers Abstract Real-world materials, particularly biological structures such as feathers exhibit complex appearances that vary spatially across their surfaces. The field of computer graphics provides a means of understanding such surfaces through material modeling which uses both analytical models and data acquired from light-surface interactions. There are many efforts within the past decade in measuring materials for graphics, but common limitations in these works include not accounting for spatially varying properties and reliance on neural networks and synthetic datasets. Feathers from modern birds present diverse appearances due to how light interacts with their unique hierarchical microstructures. Variations in those structures lead to a variety of appearances at the macroscale that inherently require a graphical model which varies spatially across the surface. In order to acquire data to help create such models, I developed software and methods to use a motorized, universal stage for sample orientation within a custom spherical illumination system, the Variable Illumination Sphere (VarIS). I also propose a pipeline for predicting, measuring, and rendering spatially varying appearances using VarIS or other systems such as goniophotometers. I take inspiration from Dupuy & Jakob's adaptive-parameterization technique in measuring Bidirectional Reflectance Distribution Functions (BRDFs), extending their approach to support spatially varying measurements from VarIS. I additionally present methods for analyzing and preprocessing data using distribution metrics and clustering that can reduce necessary capture time and storage. I acquired spatially varying appearances of a collection of feather samples across all major systematic groups of living birds, performing an analysis and fitting of the material data to achieve a relatively lightweight representation of feather light-scattering behaviors. My work presents an approach to capture complex, spatially varying appearances more efficiently and provides data for efforts in other disciplines to further understand the appearance of feathers. Committee Members: Dr. Eric Patterson, School of Computing (committee chair); Dr. Daljit Singh Dhillon, School of Computing; Dr. Adam Smith, Agriculture, Forestry, and Life Sciences; Dr. Jerry Tessendorf, School of Computing
